subdebateinfo.title: Goods and Services Tax: Input Tax Credits

talk.start.para: —My question without notice is directed to Senator Kemp, the Assistant Treasurer. Does the government agree with noted Pricewaterhouse tax expert Mr Geoffrey Lehmann's analysis that GST input tax credits are assessable income? For example, is it the case that if a business has $110,000 worth of GSTable sales and $99,000 worth of GSTable expenses then the taxable profit will be $11,000, which includes the $1,000 of net GST which will have been remitted to the ATO? Why then is the government conning small business into believing that they will not bear the burden of the GST when a noted tax expert, unlike the Assistant Treasurer, is claiming that they will? Isn't this extra taxing of small business by stealth?

talker.name: Kemp, Sen Rod
Senator KEMP
talker.role: Assistant Treasurer

talk.start.para: —I think that it is well worth while to make a few general comments on what the senator raised. If we go back into the history of tax reform, one of the driving forces behind tax reform was small business. One of the reasons that they wanted to have tax reform is that they saw that the current tax system supported by Labor was an absolutely unholy mess. That is what they saw. They wanted this government to move forward, as did the farmers, medium sized business and big business. They wanted this government to move forward and make sure that there was reform of this tax system. Let me make it quite clear that one of the big beneficiaries of tax reform is small business. We are taking billions of dollars of costs off business as a result of tax reform. We are taking billions of dollars of the cost of exports off business as a result of this tax reform. We are delivering huge tax cuts to taxpayers as a result of tax reform. Can I make it clear that we are giving real rises in pensions and benefits as a result of tax reform.

answer.para: We went to the election on tax reform, and there was one group that supported us very strongly in relation to tax reform, and that was small business. There is one group that continues to support us strongly in relation to tax reform, and that is small business.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I raise a point of order. The question as I heard it was a question about whether input tax credits are assessable income. That was the question.
—No, it wasn't.

—Yes, it was. That was absolutely the question that was asked. What we are getting is a tour, and a very feeble one, of the government's reasons for introducing a GST. Madam President, can you ask the minister, who has got only about a minute to go now, or a bit more, to please answer the direct question that has been put to him rather than fill up the available time with useless rhetoric that is probably erroneous in any case?
—There is no point of order.
—I was asked about the impact of tax reform on small business, and that is exactly what I am giving you.
—No. Input tax credits as assessable income. Answer the question, why don't you? Stop running away from it. You don't know the answer, do you. If you don't know the answer, sit down.

—Madam President, I raise a point of order. It simply cannot be acceptable to this chamber to have hysterical outbursts of the nature that Senator Cook has just imposed on us on a number of occasions. I would very much urge you to indicate to him that that sort of behaviour is totally unacceptable. He is out of control.
—I was about, before the point of order was taken, to draw your attention to the standing orders, Senator Cook. Your behaviour is unacceptable.

—I raise a point of order, Madam President. It is one of relevance. There was a clear question asked here. It is relevant that in this chamber, in which the government is supposed to be accountable, we get an answer to the question put. If the government refuses to answer it and filibusters, wastes time and dodges the answer, it is no wonder that we on this side get a bit testy. Would you direct the minister to actually answer the question that was put to him and not pad out and hide his answer between irrelevant details?

—On the point of order, Madam President: it was very clear from the question that I was asked about the impact of the GST on small business. I have outlined in detail the particular response that is required. If there is other information that the senator wants, we will always try to assist.
—You weren't asked that question, and you know it.
—I was asked about small business, and that is the answer I am giving.
—Order! The minister must relate to the subject matter that is given. Have you completed your answer, Senator?

—No, thank you, Madam President. I have not completed by answer. Madam President, can I also make the point that small business do not want to do one thing. Do you know what small business do not want to do? They do not wish to go back to the wholesale sales tax system that was part of Labor's policy. For a Labor member of the Senate to get up and attempt to pretend that small business will not benefit from tax reform is quite wrong. They are big winners, as are indeed taxpayers, as are indeed pensioners.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Maybe I should be clear and unambiguous in this question because I think that small business will be interested in the answer that the government gives. Will the minister guarantee that the net payment of GST will be tax deductible and therefore ensure that GST input tax credits are not assessable income? That is clear and unambiguous.

talker.name: Kemp, Sen Rod
Senator KEMP
talker.role: Assistant Treasurer

talk.start.para: —I am aware that there has been a debate in this area. The government is aware of this debate. Senator, this is a matter that the government will look at and it will make sure that the issue is clarified.

—My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Hill. Would the minister inform the Senate of progress in the East Timor referendum ballot? What role has Australia played in the process to date and will there be a continuing involvement?

talker.name: Hill, Sen Robert
Senator HILL
talker.role: Environment and Heritage

talk.start.para: —Yes, Australia does have an ongoing interest in the peaceful resolution of the East Timor issue. We, of course, have been a strong supporter of the process which led to yesterday's historic ballot in East Timor and we applaud the efforts of UNAMET to make the ballot such a success. Australia has played a key role in ensuring the success of the United Nations effort. We have provided significant financial and in-kind assistance. We have been a leading contributor of personnel with the largest police contingent. I would like to acknowledge the vital work that has been done by the Australian Federal Police. We certainly hope that they will be able to complete their task and return home safely.

answer.para: I am sure all senators and indeed all Australians would have been inspired by the large voter turnout yesterday and the enthusiasm shown by the East Timorese in exercising their democratic right to vote. Reports have put the voter turnout at about 90 per cent, a remarkable effort when one considers the incidents of violence and intimidation which have unfortunately marred the lead-up to the poll. There have been many media reports of East Timorese walking through the night to reach polling booths, some sleeping outside of polling booths overnight so that they could be the first to vote.

An Australian official observer delegation comprising former Deputy Prime Minister Tim Fischer, Senators Marise Payne and Vicki Bourne, and Mr Brereton has been in East Timor in the days leading up to the ballot. I would like to note that all Australians in East Timor at this time, including aid workers and members of the media, would be aware of a degree of danger, particularly given events in recent months. Their courage and ongoing commitment to a peaceful future for the people of East Timor should be recognised and applauded. Australia also recognises the efforts of the Indonesian authorities to ensure the ballot took place in an atmosphere generally free of violence.

Here in Australia the Australian Electoral Commission ensured that around 8,000 East Timorese living in Australia would have a chance to have their say on the future of their homeland. In fact, I have been told one story of an employee here in Parliament House driving up to Sydney yesterday afternoon so she could cast her vote. It is a reminder that those of us who are fortunate enough to live in a stable democracy like Australia should never take for granted our democratic right to vote. We would urge all parties involved in this process to continue to exercise the utmost restraint and, of course, to respect the outcome of the ballot. Whatever the outcome, Australia remains committed to assisting the United Nations in its continuing presence in East Timor.

talk.start.para: —My question is directed to Senator Kemp, the Assistant Treasurer. Now that the Howard government holds the all-time records for foreign debt, household debt, the worst household saving ratio on record, and the current account deficit, how can the minister explain exactly how this record constitutes fireproofing the Australian economy?

talker.name: Kemp, Sen Rod
Senator KEMP
talker.role: Assistant Treasurer

talk.start.para: —I can say to Senator McKiernan this government holds quite a few records and, Senator, we can claim record growth—over four per cent. I would have thought that was a great record and certainly it is the envy of other countries around the world. Let me talk about another record, certainly a record in the last 30 years: record low interest rates—quite a record and of enormous help, can I say, Madam President, to all home owners who have mortgages, people in business and, I might say, many of Australia's battlers. Many of Australia's battlers receive a great benefit from the record low interest rates. Let me talk about another record that I think a lot of people—
—Senator Kemp, I would remind you of the question that was put to you.

—The question was about records. Madam President, thank you for your advice on that issue but the question was on records and about how this government can claim records. I am taking the senator through some of the records which we are now claiming. A record of which I am particularly proud in relation to the economy is the record levels of productivity that we are showing, Madam President. So can I say that in that area we have been able to deliver real wage rises to Australian workers, a record which, in contrast with the record of the Labor government, is one which we are particularly proud of.

answer.para: Then, of course, we have slowed the growth of foreign debt. From memory, the servicing ratio of foreign debt under the previous government reached a record of around 20 per cent; currently, the servicing burden is around nine per cent. It is a pretty good record, I would have thought. So this government has many records of which any government would be proud. With respect to fireproofing the economy, we have had recessions in many of the major economies of Asia.
Senator Conroy interjecting—

talk.start.para: —We have had a recession, Senator Conray.
—Senator Kemp, if you are going to refer to a senator, you should use his correct name.

—Thank you, Madam President. It is well known that the Japanese economy is in recession, the Philippine economy is in recession, the Thai economy is in recession and the Indonesian economy was in recession. We faced a dreadful scene in the Asian area, a crisis the like of which we have not seen, I might say, since World War II. But what happened to the Australian economy in this period? There was strong growth in the last year of over four per cent.

answer.para: Opposition senators interjecting—

talk.start.para: —You asked about fireproofing the economy and I am telling you how we fireproofed the economy. We faced the greatest financial crisis that we have seen in the postwar era. Many of our major trading partners were in recession. They were in recession, but the Australian economy was growing—Senator Cook is looking interested, for a change—at over four per cent. (Time expired)

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. The minister has not broken his record by answering a question. I had asked him about Australian household debt, the worst household saving ratio on record and the current account deficit. I also ask: how does the minister explain the government presiding over the largest ever quarterly decline in private capital expenditure, another woeful record—this time an Australian record?

talker.name: Kemp, Sen Rod
Senator KEMP
talker.role: Assistant Treasurer

talk.start.para: —If we are talking about the CAPEX figures, which I assume you are talking about—
—He's got no idea.

—The senator is given a supplementary, and he has not got a clue. It is clear that the recent CAPEX figures showed a decline. That is correct. But the government has forecast that growth in the economy will slow—that is what we have said—and therefore there will be certain key factors, not surprisingly, which will also slow. So we have indicated that we will be coming off a very high base and that the economy will be slowing. But the forecast growth will still show that this economy is the envy of most countries around the world. It is a record that we are very proud of. (Time expired)

—My question is to the Minister for Justice and Customs, Senator Vanstone. The 1998 National Drug Strategy Household Survey was released today by the Australian Institute of Health and Welfare. I ask: will the minister explain how the government's Tough on Drugs strategy is working to address the use of illicit drugs by young Australians?

talker.name: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
Senator VANSTONE
talker.role: Justice and Customs

talk.start.para: —I thank Senator Crane for the question and for his interest in this matter. Yes, of course, I am aware of the 1998 National Drug Strategy Household Survey which was released today by the Australian Institute of Health and Welfare. It is the sixth in a series that has been going since 1985. Over 10,000 young Australians, aged 14 and over, responded. The survey covered questions in relation to drug use and knowledge and attitudes regarding drugs. It is one of the principal data collection vehicles to monitor trends and evaluate progress under the National Drug Strategy. It was conducted in July and August last year.

answer.para: Unfortunately, it did confirm the government's own assessment, and that is that illicit drug use amongst young Australians has increased during the 1990s. The government is acutely aware of the dangers that illicit drug use poses for young Australians. The government has vigorously responded to long-term increases in illicit drug use by young Australians. We have provided more than $516 million in a balanced range of measures covering law enforcement—my own particular responsibility—education, treatment and research. Of that total, $212 million—that is, 41 per cent—was specifically allocated to law enforcement. It is interesting to note that survey respondents, when asked hypothetically how they would allocate $100 towards combating use of heroin and cocaine, actually indicated that they would give $40 to that task, indicating that the mix that the government has struck between education, treatment and law enforcement programs is compatible with the expectations of young Australians in this area.

We have been working cooperatively with all the states in a bipartisan manner to introduce compulsory diversion arrangements. Drug users will be identified by police early in their relationship with the criminal justice system and directed to education, assessment and treatment. Substantial resources to all Commonwealth law enforcement agencies have been provided to intercept international and domestic drug traffickers. The results of these law enforcement efforts have vastly increased the seizures of heroin and cocaine by the Australian Federal Police. It is a direct result of better intelligence, more resources and better cooperation between agencies within the Commonwealth and between the Commonwealth and the states—working together of course to ensure that suppliers of illicit drugs face higher and higher hurdles as they want to ply their deadly trade around Australia. There is an increasing likelihood that international drug traffickers will be caught and will be prosecuted to the full extent of the law. So the government has been working to reduce demand through education, diverting users into treatment and reducing supply by getting tough on drug dealers.

It is interesting to note the support for the government's Tough on Drugs strategy: 44 per cent of those surveyed supported it, 10 per cent directly did not, and the remainder were unfamiliar with the policy and therefore could not comment. What we have been doing is acting in response to the activity that was in the community and that has now shown up as being reflected in this survey. The most alarming point is the closing gap between the drug use of males and females. It shows the importance of female role models in society who might be asked about drug issues. Those people should take into account that it is important not to be trapped into appearing `cool'. Young female role models have an important opportunity and responsibility to discourage dangerous illicit drug use by young females. When asked by the media about personal drug use, they should not respond by giggling and saying, `I'd better not answer that; it might upset my mum.' They should use the opportunity to get the `drugs are dangerous' message across to other young Australians. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —My question is to Senator Kemp, the Assistant Treasurer. How does the government explain the household debt to income ratio increasing from 80 per cent of disposable income before they came to power to 100 per cent now?
—Oh, oh!

talker.name: Kemp, Sen Rod
Senator KEMP
talker.role: Assistant Treasurer

talk.start.para: —If you don't mind, Senator Schacht, I thought that was very discourteous on your part. There are a number of reasons why household debt increases. One of the reasons, of course, is that it reflects the confidence that people have in the economy that they are prepared to borrow more. That is one of the reasons why people are prepared to go into debt. Equally, there are other factors: they are confident that, with the rise in real wages, with the low interest rates and with the rising value of asset prices, they have the capacity to borrow. So I believe we are seeing great consumer confidence in relation to the economy, and I believe recent surveys have shown that that confidence is out there in the community. So it is a reflection, on the one hand, of confidence; on the other hand, it is a reflection of the way in which these things are measured, of course. If my memory serves me correctly, this issue was very extensively discussed at recent Senate estimates hearings.

answer.para: Senator West, there is one way that this can be stopped. There is a Labor way to stop people borrowing, and Labor used it. Do you know how? They rocketed up interest rates. They lifted household interest rates to 17 per cent and heading north. That is not a policy that endears itself to this government. It was a policy endorsed by the Labor cabinet, of which Senator Ray and Senator Cook, among others, were members. They decided that one of the ways to deal with the problems they were facing was to lift the rates of interest. That is not our policy. We are a low interest rate party. We are a low tax party, and we will not go down the Labor road. But if you think the way to deal with this issue, Senator West, is to follow the Labor policy, then lift the rates of interest.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Given that the government has presided over household debt blowing out to record levels, does this also explain the 54 per cent increase in personal bankruptcies from 1995-96 to 1998-99—the three years that the Howard government has been in power?

talker.name: Kemp, Sen Rod
Senator KEMP
talker.role: Assistant Treasurer

talk.start.para: —I think that if you look closely at those issues, Senator West, you would find that some of the figures relate to credit cards. The fact of the matter is that the economy has never functioned better. This is a high-growth economy and what does Senator West want to talk about? Like all Labor senators, she wants to talk down the economy. Get out there, listen to people and listen to the opinion polls.
—Oh, yes.
—`Oh, yes,' they say. We say, `Oh, yes,' too. The reason is that people are sick of the nitpicking that Labor senators go on with. (Time expired)

—My question is to the Minister for the Environment and Heritage, Senator Hill, and it is in reference to the orange roughy fishery on the South Tasman Rise. I note that on Four Corners last night, New Zealand Minister Luxton said:

question.para: There was no quota there. The arrangement has expired so it was open in international waters.
Minister, in answer to my question yesterday, did you say:
. . . Australia and New Zealand have both agreed to ban fishing on the South Tasman Rise until a new regional agreement has been negotiated.
Minister, did you further say:
. . . I use the example of the South Tasman Rise—Australia and New Zealand both agreed on a voluntary basis to ban fishing until the stocks have been adequately assessed . . .
Can the minister tell the Senate who is correct? Is there a ban with New Zealand on fishing until a final agreement is signed or not?

talker.name: Hill, Sen Robert
Senator HILL
talker.role: Environment and Heritage

talk.start.para: —I can, perhaps, provide some further information. I am assuming that what I said yesterday was correct. There does not seem to be anything in this brief to suggest otherwise. What I have to assist the honourable senator is as follows. Australia is committed to working with other nations to protect fish stocks in our region and to ensure they are sustainably managed. Australia is working with New Zealand to establish a new fishing agreement for the South Pacific Rise. Until that agreement is finalised, both nations have an understanding not to allow fishing in the area. New Zealand is honouring that understanding. In relation to earlier incidents involving fishing vessels registered in South Africa and Belize, Australia undertook concerted diplomatic action and, with the cooperation of the governments of those two count ries, we achieved the cessation of those fishing activities.

answer.para: The government will shortly be introducing legislation that relates to implementing obligations necessary to ratify the international fish stocks agreement. The agreement and that legislation will considerably strengthen our capacity to promote and enforce sustainable fisheries management on the high seas. Our prompt and effective actions on the South Pacific Rise reflect our general concern in relation to illegal, unregulated or unsustainable fishing.

Senators would be aware that Australia is leading efforts to reduce illegal and unregulated fishing for Patagonian toothfish in the Southern Ocean. It was concern for the unsustainability of southern bluefin tuna catches that led Australia to take legal action against Japan, which senators would be aware resulted in an injunction prohibiting Japan's so-called experimental fishing program.

Whilst on that subject, I take the opportunity to congratulate Attorney-General Williams for his leadership of that case. He did a fine job on behalf of Australia. I particularly want to make mention of Senator Parer, who, as the former minister, took the lead on this issue. It was, in part, the determination of Senator Parer to stand up to the demand for unsustainable fishing levels that strengthened Australia's resolve and contributed to our taking this action, which has now brought, at least for the short term, a very satisfactory result. We hope Japan will take note that the international community believes that experimental takes should be from within allowable catches, not from without, and will cooperate fully with the commission in future. We hope, by doing so, that that will encourage other countries, such as Indonesia, Korea and Taiwan, also to come on board to ensure that the commission is more effective in the future.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Does the minister agree that, despite his answer yesterday, it was clear from Four Corners that diplomatic efforts did not work and that, even though the ships and the countries of origins were repeatedly warned, they went back under the cover of darkness for three weeks, fished, and left only when full? When the aggregation occurs next time, will Australia take stronger measures to protect this fishery?

talker.name: Hill, Sen Robert
Senator HILL
talker.role: Environment and Heritage

talk.start.para: —I am not sure what Australia is being invited to do. My advice was that the diplomatic efforts were effective in that instance. The honourable senator will know that, in circumstances within Australian waters—and I used the example of Patagonian toothfish—and in relation to waters that are covered by conventions to which we are a party, we have in the past taken even stronger action. We are committed and we are prepared not only to put in diplomatic resources but to take what efforts are necessary within the areas of our responsibility to ensure that sustainable fishing rates are achieved. We do take this matter seriously, and I would have thought that our record demonstrates that to date.

—My question is to Senator Kemp, the Assistant Treasurer. Can the minister confirm whether any individuals or organisations outside cabinet have been given access to the Ralph committee Review of Business Taxation before it is publicly released? If any such access has been given, on what terms and conditions has access been granted; was a confidentiality agreement required to be signed; and how many individuals or organisations were granted access?

talker.name: Kemp, Sen Rod
Senator KEMP
talker.role: Assistant Treasurer

talk.start.para: —The individuals who wrote the Ralph report were outside cabinet. That is the point. The question was: has anybody outside cabinet been shown the Ralph report? The first point I make is that the individuals who comprised the Ralph committee were outside cabinet.

answer.para: Senator Conroy interjecting—

talk.start.para: —You did not ask that. It is correct: those people were not in cabinet. They prepared the Ralph report after wide—

answer.para: Opposition senators interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Well, it was a dopey question. He mucked up his question; give him a chance. The point is that, in conducting the Ralph committee inquiry, there were very widespread consultations with the community. There was the opportunity for people to make submissions, and seminars were held. It is an excellent example of how this government goes about important areas of public policy—in a consultative manner. When you are conducting major reforms, you have to get out and talk to people, and that is precisely what this government did.
—Who else?
—Who else, he says now.
—Senator Kemp, I draw your attention to the question that was asked.

—Thank you, Madam President. I have already confirmed that, in relation to his question, yes, there are people outside cabinet who have seen the Ralph report. They include, of course, Mr John Ralph and the people who prepared the report. I will look at other aspects of the question that Senator Conroy has raised, and I will see whether the Treasurer is prepared to provide him with an answer.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Can the minister also confirm whether any economic modellers have been granted access to the full Ralph report or to any unreleased part? What steps has the government taken to ensure that proper confidentiality is maintained and that any privileged access to the report is not improperly used to tout for business?

talker.name: Kemp, Sen Rod
Senator KEMP
talker.role: Assistant Treasurer

talk.start.para: —This government has very strict rules and, despite the huge efforts of Senator Ray and Senator Faulkner, those great public policy men, they have never been able to shoot holes in the way that this government goes about its business. To Senator Faulkner and to Senator Ray, who decided that Labor should be a public policy free zone: you people are over there and we are over here, and that is a pretty nice solution. I always try to assist Senator Conroy in any way I can, so I will refer his question to the Treasurer to see whether he is prepared to provide him with an answer.

—My question is to the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Regional Services. Minister, in response to allegations made on the 7.30 Report last year concerning vibrating and unsafe heavy vehicles, some responsible owners have decided not to drive those vehicles on public roads. As these trucks could pose an unacceptable risk to the public and repossessions are imminent, will the minister take appropriate action to ensure that these vehicles are not sold to unsuspecting persons, thereby putting them back on the road and putting the public at risk?

talker.name: Macdonald, Sen Ian
Senator IAN MACDONALD
talker.role: Regional Services, Territories and Local Government

talk.start.para: —I thank Senator Harris for his question. Unfortunately, I do not have a lot of information about that. It refers to an issue that was reported on the 7.30 Report last year, does it?
—Yes.

—I am afraid I am not personally familiar with that, Senator. I will refer your question to Mr Anderson to see if he has some interest in it. But, having said that, it does seem to me that it would be more a matter for state governments rather than the federal government. I would have thought that it would be up to the relevant state government to have a look at those sorts of issues. talker.name: Macdonald, Sen Ian
Senator IAN MACDONALD
talker.role: Regional Services, Territories and Local Government

talk.start.para: —Again, I will refer that question to Mr Anderson and see if the report has been finalised and, if so, where it is. Senator Harris does highlight the enormous contribution the federal government makes to the national highway. We provide hundreds of millions of dollars each year for that very important infrastructure, particularly for regional Australia—and Senator Harris, as I say, rightly highlights that. As well, we provide a lot of money for roads of national importance and, of course, for the very worthwhile Black Spot program that the Labor Party cancelled and this government reintroduced. talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator HERRON
talker.role: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

—Madam President, I rise on a point of order. I am quite happy for the minister to put on the record his answer to that question, but that was not the question asked of him. He is now reading the prepared script about the aged care bill and why they have not listed it, but that is not the question.

—Order! I would remind you of the question that was asked, and I draw your attention to it, Senator Herron.

Since the coalition came to office, the number of approved places has increased from 4,431 to 13,723 places. Another 4,300 places will be available this year. The amount of funding that is going in and the fact that we are protecting the accommodation charges for pre—

answer.para: Senator Chris Evans interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Order! Senator Evans, you are out of order! Senator Herron, I would remind you of Senator Gibbs's question that you are being asked to answer.

talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator HERRON
talker.role: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

—My question is to Senator Ian Macdonald, the Minister for Regional Services, Territories and Local Government. talker.name: Macdonald, Sen Ian
Senator IAN MACDONALD
talker.role: Regional Services, Territories and Local Government

talk.start.para: —I thank Senator Coonan for that question. I appreciate it from her. She is an old country person from way back, and she obviously has an interest in rural and regional matters, unlike the Labor Party, who never ask me a question on these matters. The best thing the Howard government has done for jobs in rural and regional Australia is to get the big picture right: keep interest rates low, keep inflation low, and keep unemployment trending down. That way you give regional Australians the opportunity to get ahead and recover from the dark years of Labor.

answer.para: Senator Coonan mentioned, specifically, Eden. Whilst economies in Australia generally, including regional Australia, are going ahead very nicely, we recognise that there are some parts of Australia, particularly regional Australia, that are not doing quite as well as others, and our government is very conscious of that. Part of the reason for this is happenings beyond the control of government. For example, in Newcastle, BHP left, causing real problems. In the upper Spencer Gulf, in the Kalgoorlie-Boulder region and in northern Tasmania, there was a downturn when Australian National Rail was closed down. The government came in and provided adjustment packages in those areas, which helped private industry to expand and new businesses to come to town, and that created real long-term jobs.

Senator Coonan, as a New South Wales senator, is obviously well aware of the difficulties in Eden, where the cannery recently shut down and where a timber mill closed some time ago. That particular area has had some real problems. In conjunction with Mr Wilson Tuckey, the Minister for Forestry and Conservation, we put together an Eden region adjustment package. That package is in excess of $3.6 million, and it will provide assistance to businesses in the Eden region to expand and create real and new jobs. The $3.6 million package we put together has been added to by the New South Wales government, who put forward $250,000; and Heinz, who closed the cannery, also put forward $250,000. Our package of over $3.6 million includes direct funding to small businesses in the Eden region. As well as that, we have provided $56,000 for an Eden business challenge project, $30,500 for a new business plan for the Eden region, and $184,000 from the Rural Plan moneys for a strategic action plan in that area.

With this package we will add to expansion plans of businesses, existing and new, in the Eden region. We will not provide more than 50 per cent of the money required to expand, but the money that we do provide—less than 50 per cent of any particular project—will go to private business to expand the main criteria, being the creation of new, real, long-term jobs. That is the formula we have used in Newcastle and in the upper Spencer Gulf. We will be forming a local committee made up of local people who will investigate and assess the applications made. The applications will be called shortly.

I have to congratulate Mr Gary Nairn, the member for Eden-Monaro, who put this package to us and who has worked tirelessly for the people of the Eden community in getting the federal government to do something concrete that will provide jobs for the workers there. The Labor Party, federal and state, have no interest in jobs for workers; we do.

talk.start.para: —I move:

speech.para: That the Senate take note of the answers given by the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs (Senator Herron) to questions without notice asked today relating to aged care funding.

It became perfectly clear that the minister did not have any idea about a proper answer to the questions asked. Those are questions that went to very specific policies that are part of the government's so-called aged care reforms. Those aged care reforms are in tatters. They are falling apart at the seams. But, because of the political problems the government has had with aged care since it came to office, it is unwilling to take the remedial action necessary to fix up those things. We are increasingly seeing industry, consumers, unions and other people involved in the industry getting frustrated at the government's inability to get problems fixed because it is too scared to revisit aged care because of the political problems that it has experienced since coming to office.

The minister had no idea whether the accommodation charge was indexed. I honestly do not know. It was a good question. We would like to know the answer. The former minister, Minister Smith, said it was going to be, but he lost his seat. We have not been able to find out since. We have now got the situation where the concessional supplement paid by the government has been indexed and is now at $12.34 per day, but the accommodation charge, as far as I can tell, has not been indexed and is still at $12. I do not know the answer to the question. I would like to know the answer to the question.

My question went to the issue of coalescence, the policy decision by which the government has started to rip money out of the care subsidies provided to Victorian and Tasmanian providers. The government itself accepted that this was a policy that needed to be reviewed. It organised a review by the Productivity Commission following pressure from the industry. In January it received the report from the Productivity Commission recommending that it abandon the policy because of its inequity. Here we are at the end of August, and the minister apparently is still considering the issue. The minister considers all issues but nothing ever comes back out of her office. Nothing that is wrong in aged care, nothing that needs fixing, ever gets fixed.

What you see is a system under tremendous strain, a system bordering on collapse, because the minister refuses to deal with the fact that the aged care reforms have failed. One of the reasons the government is spending much more money—which is the defence the minister hides behind—is that the reforms have not worked. I accept that the government is spending more money on aged care. That is because the reforms have failed. The government has been forced to pay more for aged care; it has been forced to spend beyond what it was intending to spend, because its reforms have not collected the revenue it thought they were going to. The government said 27 per cent of residents in nursing homes would be concessional. It is near 47 per cent and rising. The whole basis on which the aged care reforms were erected has collapsed. Yes, the government is spending more money. That is because its aged care reforms have totally failed.

The other defence the government likes to use to the concern in the community about the increased waiting times to get family members into nursing homes and their concerns about the quality of the system is to say that the government has increased the number of residential places. In a way it has, but there are lies, damned lies and statistics. The government has increased the number of places but it has always been accepted in this community that the measure of residential places is the number per thousand of people aged 70 and over. That is the measure we have always used to assess the number of residential places in aged care in this country.

What we have seen is that over the last three years—1995 to 1998—the ratio has fallen from 92.2 residential places per thousand people aged 70 and over to 87.3. That is a drop of 4.9 places per thousand people. The minister and Senator Herron today like to say that there are 4,000 or 6,000 new places. But we have a situation where the aged population is increasing. We have far more people aged 70 and over who are in need of residential places. The accurate measure of the commitment to aged care in this country is the number of residential places per thousand people. Under this government it is falling. For the minister to try to pretend that it is not is wrong and counterintuitive. People know—and the minister's own statistics show—that it takes longer to get into a nursing home now than it used to, particularly in Victoria, where we have the worst record. In Victoria the ratio is down to 83.4 per cent per thousand people aged 70 and over.

These are the minister's figures. These are not my figures; these are departmental statistics. The problem is that the minister has not provided enough residential places. The ratio is falling; there are longer waiting lists; people are having difficulty getting into homes, getting HACC services and getting access to respite care. There are a whole range of problems in aged care that need to be addressed, but the minister refuses to address them. Coalescence is one example; accommodation charges for residents is another. The government will not address the problems. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —Labor's catcalling today is absolutely hollow and empty. It is, I guess, a reflection of the fact that they cannot admit to their own shortcomings when they were in government with regard to issues affecting older people, issues affecting aged care in nursing homes and hostels. I have said over and over again here that I give credit where credit is due and admit that the reforms they brought in to address the issues in hostels back in the late 1980s were effective and created some hostels with world-class care. But they were unable to go further and to do something about reforming the nursing home sector.

speech.para: There were a number of things. They were unable to reform the sector in that people who were living in hostels who became frail aged, especially in rural and remote areas, had to move from hostels to nursing homes, sometimes 150 or more kilometres away. They did not focus on ageing in place to enable older people to stay, especially, as I said, in remote and rural areas, where they were required to move. They did not have the foresight or the ability to do anything about that. Another thing that they did was fail to address the issue of homes of concern. The minister, in speaking in the other place in June of this year, outlined that the legacy that Labor left was appalling. She said:

I found that aged care homes which ought not to have been allowed to operate were still in oper ation, and when I looked at the record of the Labor Party I found that in the last 10 years of their rule they had closed down only four—
nursing homes—
in 10 years.
In other words, they were prepared to accept a standard which this government is not prepared to accept.

When I was in opposition I used to constantly ask, `How can this nursing home still be allowed to operate? How could this nursing home, where I would not have allowed any relative of mine to go, still be allowed to operate?' Yet Labor were not prepared to bite the bullet to address the issue and do something about reforming capital funding for nursing homes, to enable those nursing homes which had the will to do something about it to provide quality and world-class care. They were not prepared to do something about those nursing homes which were ripping off older people and did not have an interest in providing world-class care. They did nothing about the capital funding issue and nothing about those nursing homes where the standard of care was appalling.

That cannot be turned around in three years. It is like turning the Titanic around. But this government has brought in reforms to address some of those issues, enabling staying at home and enabling people to be funded in place and stay in the facility in which they start off. If they start off requiring hostel care at the beginning, then need to move on to another place of care and there is no other place for them to move to in that area, they can be cared for in place—`ageing in place'. We have addressed some of the neglect that Labor left behind.

When Labor were in government, 75 per cent of nursing homes did not meet building standards. Professor Gregory wrote a report, commissioned by the Labor Party. They were told, `Your nursing homes are not up to scratch.' I will always admit that they did do something about hostels. But they failed to do anything in the difficult area of nursing homes. Thirteen per cent of nursing homes did not meet fire standards; 11 per cent of the homes did not meet basic health standards. They cut funding to nursing homes by 75 per cent in the last four years.

They were told over and over again, especially by the Gregory report, that reforms needed to be brought into place to enable capital funding to upgrade nursing homes to an acceptable standard. There was no access to private capital funding for nursing homes and proprietors had to rely on the government. Banks were reluctant to lend to proprietors on this basis and, as I said, objective standards of building quality were not enforced. There was no protection of money for people who put money into hostels.

I could go on and on. For this Labor Party in opposition now to get up and to criticise the reforms that the coalition brought in is absolutely outrageous. They need to go back and look in the mirror at their own performance. It was appalling. It was disgraceful with respect to nursing homes and they needed to lift their game. They could now cooperate with the coalition, suggest—as I used to in opposition—ways in which changes could be made if they are legitimate and be cooperative rather than running around like Ms Macklin has over and over, scaring and frightening older people—which is their wont, something we did not do in opposition. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —We have heard Senator Patterson talk of all the wonderful things that this government has done in the aged care sector, but I say that this government has failed and failed and failed again. I want to speak today about the most important area in the aged care sector, that is, the way nurses are being reclassified, their wages are being cut and their conditions are being cut to the detriment of the patients in the nursing homes.

speech.para: I have spoken once before in this place of the reclassification process conducted by one of the larger aged care sector organisations, the Churches of Christ organisation in Queensland. Their policy was to reclassify enrolled nurses and assistants in nursing as aged care workers. This meant that assistants in nursing will suffer a loss in wages, shift penalties, one week's annual leave and their title of `assistants in nursing'. Enrolled nurses will lose up to $3,500 each year in wages as well as shift penalties, annual leave and job title.

Even more devastating in this reclassification process is the fact that, if enrolled nurses remain employed as aged care workers for three years, they lose their level of entitlement, and if they return to work as enrolled nurses they will be at the lowest classification and pay point. This reclassification program has caused an enormous amount of stress amongst nurses in this area, because they care for the job that they do and they feel that their job is important. More importantly, the patients care about it. I might add that this is only in the Queensland organisation of the Churches of Christ, that I know of. I had a phone call from the administrator in Western Australia, who assured me that this did not happen in Western Australia.

I would like to go on and talk about the impacts that these cuts have had. The Nurses Union in Queensland have conducted a 12-month report on the impact of aged care reform on nurses in Queensland. They have found that cuts in nursing hours are having a major impact on nursing staff. There was already low morale throughout the sector. Nurses have reported that 31 per cent of facilities staff are not being replaced when they leave. Extensive unpaid overtime is being worked in 32 per cent of facilities. Changes to rosters, often designed to avoid payment of meal allowances or penalty rates, and/or reduction in casual working hours as well as the shortening in shifts, are occurring in 25 per cent of facilities. Other industrial issues such as underpayment of wages are being reported in 12 per cent of facilities. The aged care sector is under extreme stress.

They also report that positions are being cut in all levels of nursing. Of the facilities that have been surveyed, 53 per cent have cut the hours of all categories of staff. For example, at one facility all staff had their weekly hours cut by one hour per week. Twenty-five per cent of facilities have cut the hours worked by registered nurses, nine per cent have cut the hours worked by enrolled nurses and 13 per cent have cut the hours worked by assistants in nursing.

What has been the result of these cuts to nursing hours? The QNU has received reports about the numbers of residents being cared for by nursing staff, and this is particularly important: reports of one registered nurse to supervise the care of between 60 and 120 residents are becoming increasingly common. This works out to the care from a registered nurse averaging 1.8 hours a day. This is less time than a domiciliary nurse spends on a daily visit. This is absolutely appalling. How can you say that the reforms of this government are good when obviously the standard of aged care in this country is decreasing all the time? (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I am amazed that the Labor Party can come in here and talk about issues such as the number of beds, aged care places per thousand of population, standards of nursing homes and funding for nursing homes when the record of the Labor government in the area of aged care was absolutely pitiful. Senator Evans talked about a fall in the number of aged care places per thousand of population as the key performance indicator for assessing service in this area. But let us have a look at the Labor record. Given that he is the shadow spokesman in this area, I am amazed that he would dare to draw anybody's attention to these matters when Labor's record is so poor. The Labor Party ran down residential care over its 13 years in office and reduced funding by some $1.5 billion. When the coalition came into office, the number of beds available for aged care was 10,000 places short of Labor's own benchmark. That is an incredible figure—10,000 residential places short of Labor's benchmark.

speech.para: The ANAO report tabled in parliament on 8 December 1998 showed a large drop in aged care places over the last 10 years the ALP was in office. In 1986 the Labor government promised that there would be 100 aged care places for every 1,000 people over 70 years of age. The actual number at that time in 1986 was 98.3 places. Ten years later—by 1996—this ratio had fallen to 93.4. Over the last decade when Labor was in office, this ratio of places per thousand population over 70 was dropping steadily. Far from being a government which provided service to the aged, it is quite obvious that the Labor Party while in government denied care to thousands of individuals who needed it. It can be said that Labor offered no vision—just an ongoing campaign based on fear and deception, and a reduction in service to the aged of this country.

When Senator Evans talks about capital funding, we have to face the fact that, sadly, Labor's record in that area is pretty bad too. In its last four years in office, Labor cut capital funding to nursing homes by 75 per cent. That is a dismal record. It is a horrendous thing to have done to the aged people of Australia—to have cut funding by 75 per cent. That is something that the Labor Party, I am sure, feels very ashamed about, and it certainly does not give Senator Evans any credibility when he comes in here and attacks the record of the coalition. The coalition's record in terms of providing funding for aged care has been very good.

The Howard government is strongly committed to ensuring that the aged care sector is able to deliver sustainable and quality aged care services for older Australians wherever they are located—not just in capital cities but in regional areas. The Howard government has introduced new capital funding arrangements for aged care facilities in order to improve the quality of buildings. As Senator Patterson said, in the past many aged care facilities were overcrowded and did not meet health or fire safety requirements. In fact, it was quite a national scandal that the old people of Australia had been left to live in such appalling conditions. The federal government now in office introduced a system—copied, I must say, from Labor—in hostels of people paying a sum which guarantees them a bed in these aged care facilities, and it is intended that this money will be used to improve the standard of accommodation in these facilities. talk.start.para: —I wish to add to the discussion about this government's agenda for aged care. The Minister representing the Minister for Aged Care in his answers to questions today avoided some of the critical issues affecting aged people, especially those needing care and especially those in Queensland. I refer to the government's own figures on the availability of and access to nursing home and hostel beds. Those figures show that, in June 1994, there were 92.5 beds per 1,000 persons aged over 70. In the four years following that date to June 1998 we moved to a situation where there were only 87.3 beds per 1,000 persons aged over 70. In a period of four years, we lost 5.2 beds for every 1,000 people who potentially could use those facilities. This is in a climate where Australia's aged population is growing. The number of places where people can access aged care is actually diminishing. The government's own target is 90 beds per 1,000 people aged over 70, made up of 40 nursing home beds and 50 hostel beds. The figures show that we are in a continual downward slide away from that target figure.

speech.para: In Queensland, this loss of access to care has resulted in a huge increase in waiting times for access to nursing home services. The average waiting time in 1997-98 was 65 days, about nine weeks, and this has blown out in 1998-99 to an average waiting time of 93 days, which is more than three months when aged and frail people are waiting to access care.

The questions that the minister should have addressed this afternoon are: firstly, who is caring for these people while they are waiting to access aged care facilities; and, secondly, what hurt and trauma is this causing elderly people themselves and their families as they wait for professional care. The answer to the first question is very clear. In Queensland it is the state government which is shouldering much of the cost of the care of elderly citizens through the public health system. This is blatant cost shifting by this government—something that this government regularly accuses the states of. This is moving the cost of care from the federal aged care budget to the Queensland state health budget. The federal government has the responsibility of providing long-term residential care to elderly Australians, and it is abrogating this responsi bility and forcing Queensland to carry the cost of aged care. This is particularly the case in the Gold Coast region, where many elderly people cannot be moved into nursing homes due to the long waiting lists and are having to be cared for in acute beds in the public health system.

The second question goes to the human side of these statistics. The question is what hurt and trauma this is causing the people themselves and their families as they wait for professional care. Everyone in this place has had the difficult phone calls from the families of elderly and unwell people who are dealing with the dilemma of affording the aged care required by their parents and the emotional difficulty and trauma of coming to a decision to actually place their aged parents into a home or hostel. The blow-out of time that these families are having to deal with—as I said earlier, it is over three months—is exacerbating that emotional difficulty faced by those families and extending the period of family discussion by months, causing extreme hurt and trauma to those families. I note the comments from Senator Herron this afternoon when he talked about the increased funds being allocated to aged care, but can I suggest that in fact the government's policy is not working. The bottom line is that there are fewer beds and that the waiting time is blowing out.

talk.start.para: —This afternoon Senator Evans took to task the Minister representing the Minister for Aged Care in that he is supposedly unable to answer a question about whether nursing home costs will be indexed. While other senators have commented on whether Senator Evans's information is reliable, I hesitate to criticise a senior senator on the other side on whether his information is reliable. However, Senator Evans's insistence that the minister must be able to answer whether costs will be indexed indicates to me a rigidity of his mind-set and that he is unable to see the real problem that faces the Australian community in terms of aged care. What is happening is that we have an ageing population. This process will continue through the years and there is unlikely to be any limit to it. Given that the population will continue to age and that the health of this population will change as well because, for example, a 70-year-old today generally speaking will be healthier than a 70-year-old, say, 30, 20 or even 10 years ago—
—What about the 90-year-old?

—We will all get old, Senator McLucas, even though you might not like it. talk.start.para: —I move:

speech.para: That the following instruments, made under section 43A of the Native Title Act 1993 , be disallowed:
(a) Native Title (Right to Negotiate—Alternative Provisions) (Northern Territory Lands Acquisition Laws) Determination 1999;
(b) Native Title (Right to Negotiate—Alternative Provisions) (Northern Territory Mining Laws) Determination 1999; and
(c) Native Title (Right to Negotiate—Alternative Provisions) (Northern Territory Petroleum Laws) Determination 1999.

Today's motion before the Senate seeks to call to an end an appalling saga of legislative malice, legislative oversight and ministerial incompetence on the part of the Commonwealth, married to the incompetence, the bad faith, and the wilful disregard for indigenous rights persistently displayed by the Northern Territory Country Liberal Party government. Section 43A of the Native Title Act was born of a compromise between Senator Harradine and the Prime Minister, a compromise designed to ensure the passage of the government's 1998 amendments to that act. The 1998 amendment package itself derived from the Prime Minister's 10-point plan, with its tenfold buckets of extinguishment of native title, and that infamous 10-point plan was a cynical and ill-considered political device.

The plan was concocted on a pretext of needing to respond to the High Court's decision on Wik. But the High Court majority in Wik found, amongst other things, that the issuing of a pastoral lease did not necessarily extinguish native title over all or part of the land subject to such a lease. Despite the fact that they also found that the rights exercisable under a pastoral lease always take precedence over any surviving native title, the government and certain interest groups embarked upon a politically motivated fear campaign in regional Australia. Just as they did after the Mabo decision in 1992, they deliberately set out to spread fear and misinformation. In a conscious response to the perceived need to outflank the emerging One Nation ranks to their right, they threw everything into this campaign. So the 10-point plan was not a response to real issues; it was a response to the fear and misinformation that they themselves had set out to nurture.

There was another fundamental error intrinsic to the Howard-Harradine compromise. It is an error that has been repeated a number of times since, particularly in this place. I fully understood the anxiety being expressed at that time that the Senate impasse on the government's native title legislation could lead to a race based double dissolution election. I accept that Senator Harradine, at least, proceeded with goodwill and a sincere desire for solutions. But real problems and differences in the community should be addressed by going to the root causes of such conflicts, not by quick and secret deals.

You cannot simply wish a problem away. And there is more than a touch of middle-class niceness in the view that seems to hold that the biggest problem facing the nation is the anxiety about unseemly squabbles between the nation's elected representatives. We cannot sweep all our issues under a carpet of media relief and short-term self-congratulation. But that seems to be a prevailing view. The big issues are the real issues, the things on which politicians will rightly and properly differ from time to time. A deal cut to take an issue or a piece of legislation off the parliamentary agenda solves nothing in itself. Issues of national significance—be they native title, environmental protection, the plight of indigenous peoples or the plight of the poor and the unemployed—will keep on coming back until we get it right. They will not go away when we cut deals to stop talking about them.

So we are here essentially to address solutions to the nation's problems, not solutions to momentary government problems. The government's problem under debate at this time arose from the Prime Minister's inflexibility. It is the same man who cannot say sorry; who can find only spurious solutions, not real answers, to problems created by him and his deliberate campaign to outflank, as I said earlier, One Nation on the right. The promise of `bucketloads of extinguishment' was to be accompanied and enhanced by a severe wind back of the application and effectiveness of the native title claimants' right to negotiate. But let us remember, in the context of the Native Title Act of 1993, that that act confirmed the validity of every interest in land granted since European settlement of this country, including the arguably invalid interests granted after the enactment of the Racial Discrimination Act of 1975. In recognising the possible survival of native title in some places it did not give potential holders of such title any right to veto the grant of later interests such as was given, for instance, in the Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act.

In order to counterbalance the override of the RDA and thereby remain consistent with Australia's obligations as a signatory to the Convention on the Elimination of Race Discrimination, the 1993 NTA gave native title claimants a substantive and procedural right—the right to negotiate. Then in 1998, the Labor Party, the Democrats, the Greens and, in the first instance, Senator Harradine rejected government amendments that removed the right to negotiate where native title coexisted with later granted interests.

Essentially, we are today debating this motion because Senator Harradine found a way for the Prime Minister to save face at that time. Without consultation and without the consent of those whose rights were being diminished, Senator Harradine and the government devised a scheme whereby the substantive procedural protection for native title in situations of coexisting tenures was able to be removed. They drafted section 43A as an amendment to the act. That amendment gave states and territories the capacity to replace the right to negotiate available under the Commonwealth legislation with alternative and potentially inferior rights and procedures legislated and administered by the states and territories.

The problems being addressed by the amendment were not ones of workability or of equity but the political problems of the Prime Minister—his problems with his backbenchers, his problems with the National Party and their problems with One Nation, and his problems with the need to be seen to address the spurious problems concocted in a fear campaign in which he was complicit. It was a secret deal done behind closed doors. It was a deal which had, and still has, the potential to erode indigenous rights far more, I must say, than I am sure Senator Harradine may have imagined.

But with the government's focus on the wrong game, it is fair to say that they botched it. I accept that Senator Harradine was unaware, and let us accept for argument's sake that the government were unaware, of the dangerous loopholes in that legislation. Whatever the facts are on the matter, the loopholes still exist. Let us remember that the Native Title Act contains some 35 disallowable instruments. Delegations of responsibilities, procedures and powers under this act were held to need special scrutiny by the parliament, and this is one of them. But with regard to this one, the legislation has a fundamental flaw for, whilst an approval by the Attorney-General of such a scheme under 43A(1)(b) of the act is disallowable, any later amended scheme is free from any parliamentary scrutiny.

This is a critical issue in considering the scheme put forward by the Northern Territory government—the proposal before us today. In this case it has to be said that the Commonwealth in general, and the Attorney-General in particular, made the worst of a potentially bad situation and, in doing so, they gave the show away. By giving preliminary advice in February of this year and a final determination in April that the Territory scheme complies with 43A(1)(b) of the act, I think the Attorney-General made a fool of himself and a mockery of the process. Everybody but the A-G knew in April that the Northern Territory scheme was non-compliant, unworkable and inadequate. But in giving it the tick at that time, he let the cat out of the bag. It is now clear that what is acceptable to him is something substantially less than what even the Northern Territory government now thinks is acceptable. He set a low benchmark for the future, and that should send a signal to anyone in this place concerned about the benchmarks in the legislation.

To accentuate the A-G's embarrassment, the Territory government has since seen fit to make a number of amendments to its scheme. It did so in June this year. A number of issues between stakeholders that were raised in the process—one that Senator Harradine and his advisers have in many ways presided over—are yet to be seen reflected in formulated amendments. They may very well be in the future. The problem is that all this cleaning up that has taken place since the A-G's determination can be thrown out by the Northern Territory government when it sees fit. This debate finishes at 6.50 p.m. They can meet tonight and change the legislation. They can meet tomorrow. If we fail in our disallowance motion today, the Senate will never be able to—
Senator Harradine interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Senator Harradine is shaking his head. Senator Harradine, even a first-year articled law clerk will tell you that. I do not know what your advisers are on at the moment, but even a first-year articled law clerk can tell you that is the case.
—You're behind the play.

—I am behind the play! I do not know what pack you are leading, Senator Harradine, but I have had good advisers here. The play essentially is that the Northern Territory government can meet tonight and change the legislation. If we do not carry this disallowance motion today, we will never see it again. That is the play; that is the loophole in the legislation. It is one that you cannot run away from and it is one that your legal advisers cannot run away from, unless they want to reduce themselves to the level of first-year articled law clerks. That is the problem. In identifying that problem, there has been advice around for quite some time, Senator Harradine, and you know it. And the most recent advice comes from a no less eminent source than the Clerk of the Senate.
—Why didn't you say an eminent source?

—I said `a no less eminent source', Senator Hill. You may guffaw as you like, and so may Senator Harradine. I asked a couple of questions last week about this mechanism in the legislation—the security under the alternative provisions after the time for disallowance of a determination is passed. The advice is clear:

speech.para: . . . it is clear that there is nothing to prevent the amendment by a state or territory of alternative right-to-negotiate provisions after the time for disallowance of a determination by either House of the Commonwealth Parliament has passed. Such provisions would operate as amended so long as the Commonwealth minister's determination is not revoked by the minister. Amendments could significantly alter the provisions, but the Senate would not be able to prevent such amendments.

Native Title Act—Section 43A Determinations

Advice has been sought on the affect of the notice of motion for the disallowance of three instruments made under paragraph 43A(1)(b) of the Native Title Act 1993, given by Senator Bolkus on 23 June 1999. On the current sitting pattern, the notice is due to be dealt with on 31 August 1999.

Each of the three instruments that are the subject of the disallowance notice determine that certain laws of the Northern Territory, proposed to apply as alternative right to negotiate procedures, meet the threshold criteria for such alternative procedures set out in subsections 43A(4) and (6), and meet the requirements of subsection 43A(7), of the Native Title Act 1993.

Section 43A of the Native Title Act 1993 allows the Commonwealth Minister to determine that provisions of a State or Territory law comply with certain threshold criteria. When such a determination is in place then those State or Territory provisions apply instead of the right to negotiate provisions in Subdivision P of Division 3 of Part 2 of the Native Title Act. Under section 214 of the Native Title Act, such determinations are disallowable instruments for the purposes of section 46A of the Acts Interpretation Act 1901. This means that the provisions in Part XII of the Acts Interpretation Act for the scrutiny and disallowance of regulations apply to such instruments.

The effect of disallowing a determination under paragraph 43A(1)(b) of the Native Title Act is that, in the absence of any authorised alternative State or Territory provisions, the right to negotiate provisions of the Native Title Act itself apply.

Section 43A of the Native Title Act provides once-only parliamentary scrutiny of the alternative right to negotiate provisions. However, if the provisions are amended so that they no longer comply with the threshold requirements set out in subsections 43A(4) and (6), the Commonwealth Minister must, pursuant to subsection 43A(9), advise the State or Territory Minister of the non-compliance and if, after 90 days, the provisions still do not comply, the Commonwealth Minister must either revoke the determination or allow a further period of 90 days for the State or Territory Minister to bring the provisions back into compliance. The effect of revocation of a determination is that the alternative State or Territory provisions cease to be authorised and, therefore, the Native Title Act provisions in Subdivision P of Division 3 of Part 2 of the Act again apply. The Commonwealth Minister's determination to allow a further 90 days for the State or Territory Minister to amend the provisions is also disallowable. The effect of disallowing such a determination would be to require the Commonwealth Minister to revoke the determination authorising non-compliance provisions without further delay.

Once a determination under paragraph 43A(1)(b) is in place, the State or Territory Minister may amend (or initiate the amendment of) the provisions without further reference to the Commonwealth Parliament, provided that the provisions continue to meet the threshold criteria.
Section 10A of the Acts Interpretation Act 1901 provides that:

Where an Act contains a reference to a short title or other citation that is or was provided by the law of a State or Territory for the citation of a law of that State or Territory as originally enacted or made or as amended, then, except so far as the contrary intention appears:
(a) the reference shall be construed as a reference to that law as originally enacted or made and as amended from time to time . . .

It is argued in the explanatory statements accompanying the determinations which are the subject of the disallowance notice (for example in the footnote on page 3 of the explanatory statement to the Native Title (Right to Negotiate—Alternative Provisions) (Northern Territory Mining Laws) Determination 1999) that by reason of section 10A and paragraph 46(1)(a) of the Acts Interpretation Act 1901, a reference in the determination to a law of a Territory is construed as a reference to the law as originally enacted or as amended from time to time. This appears to be a reasonable assumption. If this were not the case, then the Commonwealth Minister would need to revoke and remake determinations every time there was a minor change in the relevant State or Territory law.

Conceivably, amendments of the provisions which are the subject of the paragraph 43A(1)(b) determinations could provide for less favourable conditions than those originally determined as acceptable by the Commonwealth Minister, but, unless the provisions fall below the threshold level, the Commonwealth may take no action. While the Commonwealth Minister has a continuing role to ensure that the provisions remain acceptable, and must revoke a determination if they do not, the Commonwealth Parliament's role is limited to scrutiny of the paragraph 43A(1)(b) determination and any extension of time under subparagraph 43A(9)(c)(ii). Even if, after amendment, the provisions fail to meet the section 43A threshold criteria, the Parliament has no further role in the process unless a fresh determination under paragraph 43A(1)(b) is made.

With regard to the determinations that are the subject of Senator Bolkus's disallowance notice, I have not been able to establish whether any of the provisions which are cited in the determinations have subsequently been amended. There is no requirement for a State or Territory Minister to notify the Commonwealth Parliament of any such amendments. However, the effect of a disallowance motion is quite clear. If the motion is agreed to then the Northern Territory provisions will not apply and the original Native Title Act provisions will continue to apply. It is irrelevant to the ultimate effect of the disallowance whether the provisions referred to in the determination are the provisions as they were at the date when the determinations were made or as they may be, after amendment, on the date of disallowance. However, as this question may be relevant to a decision by senators whether to vote for or against the disallowance motion, it is my view that disallowance of the determinations would represent a rejection of the provisions as they stood at the date of disallowance. The alternative interpretation (that the disallowance would affect only the provisions as they were at the date of making and not their amended form at the date of disallowance) would render parliamentary control of these instruments ineffective.
