MAJOR SHORTFALLS IN THE NORTHERN TERRITORY LEGISLATION

The limited scope of the brief negotiations between the Land Councils and the Northern Territory government did not permit a more detailed investigation of many issues relevant to the protection of native title. There are at least eight major shortfalls in the Northern Territory legislation which are fundamental to the protection of native title and were discussed at length with Northern Territory government officers prior to 23 June. There are other very appropriate initiatives which, due to the very limited contact between the Northern Territory government and the Land Councils, were not even broached in discussions (for example, the provision of indigenous input into the appointment of Tribunal members)
The eight shortfalls that were discussed with the Northern Territory government are:

The Nature of Objection: The trigger for the consultation process under the scheme is the lodgement of an objection to a proposed act or acts by a registered claimant. The formal requirements for lodging an objection (without which native title claimant would have no standing) places an indeterminate and unnecessarily onerous obligation on registered native title claimants and bodies corporate.

The real possibility that a registered claimant could be denied standing on a technicality is unacceptable. Time constraints in correcting a technical problem could determine that a registered claimant be locked out of the consultation process.
Lodgement of objections: Any time limited scheme needs to have a degree of flexibility if it is to demonstrate administrative fairness.
When the clock starts running on a process, respondents can be at a disadvantage.
The Territory scheme will still use the national registration system.
However, there is no requirement for the National Native Title Tribunal to give priority to applications lodged in response to a notice given under a Northern Territory scheme.
It is possible that due to no other factor than the human resources available, a claim could still be awaiting processing at the national level whilst the Northern Territory process reaches finality.
The Northern Territory legislation should provide discretion for a Minister to extend the time period for the registration of a native title claim in such circumstances.

Agreements: The consultation process fails to promote resolution of objections by agreement by providing the necessary focus and real substance to consultations. Neither does it provide agreements entered into under the Territory legislation with sufficient legal status to resolve all or part of a proposal.

Effect Conditions: There is insufficient connection in the scheme between Lands and Mining Tribunal recommendations or the terms of agreements lodged in resolution of an objection and the instrument of grant itself. The scheme should provide that conditions of the grant of the proposed mining interest must be endorsed on the instrument of grant.
How otherwise are the conditions to be enforced?

Complaints procedure: With or without such endorsement, the Mining and Petroleum Acts lack a serious complaints procedure to ensure timely and cost-effective compliance with the terms of grants under those Acts. Indigenous interests need some assurance that this is more than a sham process.

Limitation period on claims: The Northern Territory Scheme unreasonably imposes a three year time limitation on claims for compensation circumstances where the Native Title Act 1993 does not have such a limitation.
This is yet another example of the territory scheme being a markedly inferior alternative to rights available to indigenous interests under the Native Title Act.
Non-disclosure of cultural information: This issue is yet another illustration of the ingrained culture of cultural insensitivity in the Northern Territory government.
The Lands and Mining Tribunal Act 1998 does not protect confidential, cultural evidence heard or subpoenaed in proceedings of the Tribunal from disclosure in other proceedings.

Compensation: the legislative provisions dealing with compensation in the Territory scheme are unnecessarily rigid, preventing the low cost resolution of matters where the compensation involved is not significant. The Tribunal should be required, where determining that an act may be done, to also determine that compensation be paid into trust.
If not, the act may be done, the profits dispersed and the proponents long gone before a formal legalistic compensation process is complete.
These eight points are far from insubstantial. However, the Northern Territory government has dismissed them as such.
Despite these concerns being put before them before its last round of legislation in June, the government has not engaged in meaningful negotiations on them.
However, now that the matter is before the Senate, we are hearing a new flurry of public utterances and assurances that these matters can be dealt with.
Well let them be dealt with.
And let the security issue be dealt with.
And let the Land Councils be thoroughly resourced to deal with these matters on behalf of their constituents.

talk.start.para: —It is certainly the view of the government that it would be a tragedy if the ALP succeeds today in, in effect, voting down the new alternative scheme that has been put up by the Northern Territory government—a tragedy in such circumstances in which the Northern Territory legislation not only meets the statutory requirements of the Commonwealth act but also is fair. The Northern Territory government has put forward a proposition that is workable and, in being workable, can address the backlog that everyone acknowledges. It would be a tragedy if, as a result of the ALP's determination to win short-term political points, development and jobs and, in particular, the opportunities for jobs and economic betterment of indigenous people in the Northern Territory suffer.

speech.para: What I want to do is to put some facts on the table in relation to the process that has led the Northern Territory to the development of the legislation that is being debated in this chamber through this disallowance motion and then at the end to come back to the motivation of the ALP in being so determined to defeat the Northern Territory in its objective to put in place a workable, locally based scheme for addressing these development issues.

An integral part of both the original and the amended Native Title Act of 1993 is the facilitation of alternative state regimes. State governments have always had responsibility for the management of land, including the issuing of mining tenements. It makes sense to allow the states and territories to integrate native title processes into their existing land management systems. The Northern Territory government has therefore chosen to pursue a section 43A determination for their mining, petroleum and land acquisition laws. The Northern Territory government first embarked on a section 43A scheme in August of last year and, since, has worked hard to create a scheme which, as I said, complies with the section 43A criteria, satisfies the genuine concerns of the representative Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander bodies and provides a workable land management system in the Northern Territory.

Section 43A was approved by the Senate as part of the Native Title Amendment Bill 1997. Section 43A allows state and territory governments to introduce alternative schemes to the right to negotiate on what are essentially pastoral lease lands if their schemes satisfy the criteria set out in section 43A. The criteria have been agreed as an appropriate package of procedural rights over pastoral lease land where the native title rights are likely to be coexisting rights rather than rights of exclusive possession. The process by which state or territory legislation is allowed to operate requires the Commonwealth minister to be satisfied that the criteria are met, with that decision being subject, of course, to parliamentary review through tabling and disallowance and possibly judicial review.

The criteria in section 43A guarantee native title claimants as well as native title holders certain procedural rights—in particular, the right to be notified; a right to object to the act in so far as it affects registered native title rights and interests; a right to be consulted on heritage and access issues for the purpose of minimising the impact of their native title rights and interests; a right to have an objection heard by an independent person or body; a right to a judicial review of the decision to do the act and conditions on the minister overriding the decision of the independent body; and the right to compensation. I stress: these procedural rights must be provided irrespective of rights held by others with an interest in the land.

With that background, on 27 April 1999, the Commonwealth Attorney-General determined that the Northern Territory provisions comply with the criteria established by the parliament in section 43A. The Attorney-General tabled the determinations in the Senate on that day and in the House of Representatives on 11 May 1999. Prior to making these determinations, the Attorney-General invited and considered submissions from the land councils in the Northern Territory. The Attorney made a visit to the Northern Territory to meet with representatives of the Central Land Council and to hear their concerns face to face. The Northern Territory government has passed amendments to address most of the concerns that were raised by the land councils in that submission process. The result is that the Northern Territory scheme not only meets the criteria set out in section 43A but also goes beyond the criteria in that section.

Parts of this scheme replicate the provisions of the right to negotiate. In particular, the time limits in the Northern Territory scheme are similar to those in the right to negotiate, the compensation provisions are largely the same as the right to negotiate, and the Northern Territory's independent body—the Lands and Mining Tribunal—has a similar de jure of independence to the National Native Title Tribunal. The Northern Territory scheme, like the right to negotiate, places emphasis on resolving issues through agreement. It is important to note that no-one is disputing the fact that the Northern Territory scheme not only meets the criteria of section 43A but also goes beyond those criteria. The development of the Northern Territory's alternative schemes has been a long and detailed process and has led to the first genuine negotiations between the representative bodies in the Northern Territory—the land councils—and the Northern Territory government on issues of native title.

The Northern Territory government has displayed a willingness to amend the section 43A schemes, in response to comments made by the land councils. For example, the land councils made a comprehensive 120 page submission on the Northern Territory scheme to the Commonwealth Attorney-General. The submission raised about 95 different issues. Of these 95 issues raised in the land councils' initial submission, the Northern Territory has passed legislation addressing around 85 per cent of the issues. Further, almost all of the issues raised did not relate to the compliance of the scheme with the section 43A criteria; therefore the Northern Territory passed amendments, not because it was required to but as a display of good faith towards addressing the land councils' concerns. I would suggest that, in those circumstances, disallowing the Northern Territory determinations would severely damage the developing, positive relationship between the Northern Territory government and the land councils.

As I have already mentioned, in addition to the consultation between the Northern Territory government and the land councils, the Commonwealth Attorney-General undertook a comprehensive consultation process with the land councils. This consultation process included early informal briefings, provision of explanatory material, many discussions between officials, and a meeting between the Attorney-General and representatives of the CLC.

So we come to the circumstances of today. What I think is not in dispute is, firstly, that the Northern Territory legislation complies with the Commonwealth legislation. Secondly, it goes beyond the Commonwealth legislation and provides for a number of other procedural matters that enhance the opportunities of indigenous people. Furthermore, in developing the legislation, the Northern Territory government has listened to the issues and concerns of indigenous people where they have gone beyond the procedural requirements of section 43A, as evidenced by the fact that the Northern Territory government has gone back and amended its legislation after the Commonwealth Attorney-General had already given recognition to the fact that the Northern Territory legislation met the statutory requirements of the Commonwealth act.

In those circumstances, we find the ALP determined to vote down the new Northern Territory scheme, and one has to ask why. The answer, I would suggest, is apparent to all. On indigenous matters, the ALP has become extremely negative; arguably, even destructive. I know it was disappointing to the ALP—frustrating, perhaps—to see the amendments to the native title legislation passed in this place last year, but that is democracy. The legislation was amended in a way in which the majority in this place believed it would be more effective in addressing new issues that arose out of the Wik case—more effective, more practical, more usable. These were the decisions of this place. It may be frustrating to the ALP that the legislation put down when they were in government was amended, but that is a fact of life. But would the ALP go forward upon that and look to constructively contribute to helping make the new scheme work? No, the ALP is determined to bring it down. This is the first opportunity that the ALP has had to address an alternative states based rights scheme, developed in accordance with the legislation that was passed by this place, and the ALP has indicated today that it is determined to see it fail. What would be the consequences of that? Sadly, the consequences would be to return those in the Northern Territory to the trenches.

Things have changed in the Northern Territory that the Australian Labor Party is not prepared to recognise. The Northern Territory government is a conciliatory government that is looking to build new bridges with indigenous people. The ALP is not prepared to recognise that, of course, because it sees that it undermines a traditional constituency. So rather than recognising that there is an opportunity to go forward, the Labor Party is determined to drag the parties in the Northern Territory backwards. It is determined to drag them backwards to what, for the ALP, is the old comfort zone in which it simply supports the land councils against the Northern Territory government—ground that it knows well.

Unfortunately for ALP, it has never been able to win government in the Northern Territory, and that is an ongoing frustration. The reason it has not is because it has not been prepared to embrace the total constituency of the Northern Territory, and it is not today prepared to recognise that the people of the Northern Territory want to go on. They want to see that the scheme that they have implemented, put in place, and passed through their parliament in accordance with the requirements of the Commonwealth legislation is put into effect.

What the people of the Northern Territory want now is to tackle the backlog. I think Senator Tambling will give some further information, but as I understand it there is a backlog of some 900 applications, and the Northern Territory people want to get on with tackling that backlog, because they are interested in development and jobs. And if the development and jobs are pursuant to the safety requirements that were written into the Commonwealth legislation, why shouldn't they be allowed to get on with their own business, implement their new piece of legislation, and start to create a climate in which development can occur and indigenous jobs can be created? But, no, this Labor Party is not prepared to go forward. It is frustrated and irritated by the fact that it lost the native title debate last year. It is frustrated and irritated by the fact that it lost the preamble debate only a matter of weeks ago, when it had an opportunity to be constructive and go forward, when it saw the signals of new senators coming into this place, but it was not prepared to remodel itself towards the future. It wanted to dwell on the past, and it is frustrated by the fact that it made such a fool of itself in relation to the reconciliation motion that went through in this place only a few days ago.

On all of these issues there is no signal from the ALP that it is prepared to learn in indigenous matters and move forward. It wants to drag the debate back to the old days of confrontation. The trouble for the ALP is that circumstances within Australia have changed. People such as Lowitja O'Donoghue recognise that it has changed. Listen to the Prime Minister and you see that it has changed. Listen to the Australian Democrats and you see that it has changed. Indigenous people want to move on. They want to concentrate on what is necessary to produce jobs and to provide housing and education for their children in circumstances that can be achieved through better economic outcomes. That is where the debate for the future is—in a constructive and positive debate—and the Northern Territory government has provided the framework for that through its legislation that the ALP, federally, is now determined to vote down.

What is the basis on which they are seeking to justify their case? The first is the one of security. The Commonwealth legislation provides the safeguard. It provides a threshold. The Northern Territory government cannot legislate below the threshold. They cannot go out and amend their legislation to have effect below the threshold, and Senator Bolkus knows that. So that is a furphy.

Secondly, Senator Bolkus says he is not convinced that the Northern Territory government is genuinely prepared to tackle the backlog. The facts of life are that the Northern Territory government has already actively pursued the possibility of an agreement on how to deal with the outstanding applications, including by amending the legislation to provide a mechanism for staggering the applications in consultation with the land councils and offering financial assistance to facilitate a framework agreement between the land councils and the miners. So that argument does not carry any weight.

The third shallow reason given by Senator Bolkus is that there are still some differences between the position of the Northern Territory legislation and the total ambit bid of the two land councils. As I said, 85 per cent of the Northern Territory land council's bid has been taken out and put into legislation, well beyond the minimum threshold provided in the Commonwealth legislation. If one looks at the eight remaining issues which Senator Bolkus says stand between both positions, one will find that they amount to very little. With a Northern Territory government that is prepared to work in a constructive way, those very few outstanding issues can easily be sorted out.

In other words, on any objective analysis there is no basis on which to come in here today and vote down the Northern Territory's legislation. That is why I say we can have no doubt that the real objective of the ALP is to continue in its currently destructive mode on indigenous affairs, to continue to block and make it difficult for those who want to go forward. If that is the best they can do for the future, not only will they lose the rest of the Australian constituency but in the end they are going to lose the indigenous constituency as well. It is already happening when you see the attitude of indigenous people now wanting to get on and build partnerships, build new relationships with governments, and get some really decent economic outcomes for their benefit. In their desire, they are constantly being frustrated by this negative, carping ALP.

The Labor Party has bid itself out of indigenous affairs at the moment. It is not prepared to offer anything new or positive for the future. If from that background they are successful today in frustrating the attempts of those who want to build bridges and move forward in a constructive way, I would suggest that that would be a matter that amounts to a great tragedy. I urge honourable senators, those who still have the capacity to affect the outcome of this debate today, to back the Northern Territory government, in its constructive mode, to implement its new legislation, which is both fair and workable. Let's put the real effort into providing economic outcomes for the benefit of all Northern Territorians, particularly for indigenous Northern Territorians who are badly in need of these economic opportunities and really do want us to move forward in this debate, not constantly backwards.

talk.start.para: —I wish to speak in this debate on the disallowance of various instruments made under section 43A of the Native Title Act 1993. The 1998 amendments to the Native Title Act expanded the range of circumstances where the right to negotiate may be replaced by alternative procedures. Under section 43A of the amended Native Title Act, states and territories may replace the right to negotiate with alternative procedures which may be less favourable to native title holders, and I might add, which may then in fact provide not security but insecurity to all the stakeholders.

speech.para: Before state and territory alternative provisions under section 43A are accepted, however, the Commonwealth Attorney-General must make a determination that the scheme complies with the series of standards outlined in the act. The minister's determination is then subject to disallowance by the Senate. That is what brings us to this debate this afternoon.

The Democrats have several concerns with the Northern Territory's alternative schemes under section 43A which the opposition has moved to disallow today. Let me put those on the record. Firstly, there is the issue of the content of the scheme. We note that there are still some unresolved issues with the legislation itself. However, I do want to acknowledge that through negotiations a great deal of amendment has already been made to the Northern Territory's original scheme.

Secondly, there is the issue of the backlog of mining applications, which presents great difficulties. We understand that part of the reason for the backlog is that the Northern Territory government, under its previous leader, did not use the provisions under the Native Title Act to deal with these applications. So it is a bit rich to blame indigenous people for the backlog. Our discussions with the Northern Land Council suggest funding requirements may yield to a solution in the future in order to deal with the backlog of these applications. However, the Democrats accept that that is a matter which would need to be resolved through further negotiation between the Northern Territory government and the land councils. That would certainly have to be a proper resolution. Thirdly, there is the issue of future security for state and territory regimes. This is our biggest concern.

During the Wik debate, the Democrats made clear our opposition to the Commonwealth handing over its responsibility in relation to the right to negotiate to state and territory governments. Our objections at the time were based on three factors. Firstly, the 1967 referendum gave power to the Commonwealth to make laws on behalf of indigenous Australians. This power has never been rescinded by any subsequent referendum. We believe, therefore, that the Commonwealth, in seeking to hand power to the states and territories, is abrogating the responsibility given to it under the amended Constitution. Secondly, the Democrats' experience in seeking to advocate for indigenous people has been mostly negative in regard to state and territory governments. I should indicate that my own experience in this area extends over 37 years, both in Queensland and at a national level. The third concern relates to the findings of the United Nations Committee on the Elimination of Racial Discrimination, which states that amendments to the native title legislation appear to:
. . . wind back protections of indigenous title offered in the Mabo decision of the High Court of Australia.
In its findings, the CERD singled out:
. . . restrictions concerning the right of indigenous title holders to negotiate with non-indigenous land users as one area of the Wik amendments which are particularly discriminative.

The lack of any provision for ongoing Senate scrutiny of future amendments to state and territory alternative regimes has been the most crucial issue for the Democrats in deciding whether or not to support the opposition's motion to disallow the Northern Territory's alternative regime. Without ongoing Senate scrutiny, there will be absolutely nothing to stop state and territory governments amending existing provisions, provided they still meet the minimum standards outlined in the Native Title Act, at any time in the future. This means that, without Senate scrutiny, there can be no guarantee that state and territory alternative regimes will be favourable to native title holders in the future. It is important to note that these minimum standards significantly water down the right to negotiate provisions contained in the Commonwealth regime. One example is that the duty on governments and grantee parties to negotiate in good faith about all issues under the Commonwealth regime can be replaced with a duty to consult with native title holders. In reality, this may simply mean supplying native title holders with adequate information on a proposed development and allowing a reasonable time for a response. That is quite a different thing.

Despite these problems, during our meeting and discussions with the Chief Minister, we were impressed with his sincerity, and we have acknowledged the efforts he has made to find common ground with the land councils. We believe there is a genuine desire to improve the past record in regard to race relations in the Northern Territory. We also believe that the Northern Territory land councils have made great efforts to find a way through to a solution. We have been most grateful for their advice and availability over the last few days. The problem is that, even with goodwill on both sides, we are yet to find a solution to this impasse.

In determining our final position, the Democrats are convinced that the broader issue of security is the critical one. Without ongoing Senate scrutiny, there can be no guarantee that state and territory alternative regimes will be favourable to native title holders in the future. There will be absolutely nothing to stop state and territory governments amending existing provisions, provided they still meet the minimum standards outlined in the Native Title Act, at any time in the future. I heard what the minister said, but the problem for the Democrats is that we believe the Attorney-General would accept far too low a standard in signing off on those state regimes.

As for solutions to the impasse, I understand that there are at least three possible options for addressing the security issue. One would be an amendment to the Commonwealth's Native Title Act to make provision for ongoing Senate scrutiny of any future state or territory amendments to section 43A alternative schemes. The second would be an indigenous land use agreement between the government of each state and territory and the relevant indigenous representative bodies. The third would be to disallow every state and territory regime so that the provisions for the right to negotiate would be covered by section 43 of the Commonwealth Native Title Act. In effect, this would mean working through the National Native Title Tribunal.

I am not going to say at this stage which of those is the preferred solution because I do not know. All of them have problems. In discussions with various stakeholders, all of them have raised problems with each of those solutions. But I commit myself to continuing those kinds of negotiations and discussions so that a way through to a solution can be found. Therefore, the Democrats have decided to support the disallowance, primarily because of our grave concerns about the security question. We are hoping that this disallowance will pave the way for further negotiations with federal, state and territory governments on ways to overcome the problems with which we are faced.

In the time remaining to me I would like to deal with some of the myths that surfaced in this debate. Those myths concern the whole operation of the Native Title Act through the Native Title Tribunal. But before doing that, I would also like to acknowledge the work of the Northern Land Council and the Central Land Council. We did ask them to put on paper the problems that they have with the various issues in terms of both the mining applications and also the legislation as it now stands. I notice Senator Bolkus is not here, and I know he tabled something similar to this, but I seek leave to table this letter so that it also can be part of the record.

talk.start.para: —Is leave granted?
—Have the courtesies been extended?
—No.
—You may circulate that now through the chamber and then at the end of your speech seek leave to have it incorporated.

—Yes. I apologise to the chamber. I would have done that earlier, but I have just received the letter. If I could return to the issue of the operation of the Native Title Act through the Native Title Tribunal, I would like to acknowledge the help they have given me today in bringing me up to date on the way things are in terms of that tribunal. In the media there is a lot of myth in claims which are made about the National Native Title Tribunal and whether or not it has ability to deal with the issues which come before it.

speech.para: Let me put on the record some of these facts. Indigenous land use agreements are now possible. These help miners, local government and others to go about their business while protecting native title interests of indigenous people. Important legal benefits flow from registering agreements under the Native Title Act. In relation to formal determinations, since 30 September 1998, there have been two more voluntary agreements to settle native title applications—known as consent determinations—involving the Moa and Saibai islands in the Torres Strait. And there are more to come. To date there have been five consent determinations nationally, all of which are in Queensland and New South Wales. In addition, there have been four litigated determinations at the national level. In relation to consolidation of claims, the stringent new registration test which determines whether claimants have the right to have a say over mining, exploration and the like is being applied to most existing claims and all new claims. The tribunal has tested about 40 per cent of the claims nationwide; about 349 remain to be tested.

In relation to decisions to date on registration tests, at a national level 225 claims have been tested, of which 106 have passed and 119 have failed. This is causing many claimants to think about the merits of their applications in the face of the stringency of the registration test, and they are deciding in some cases to withdraw or combine. In Western Australia this has been most profound, with one-third fewer claims—down to just over 200 now—than there were at the start of the Wik legislation. For miners and explorers this means that they have fewer claimants to deal with and can negotiate with some confidence that they are dealing with people who have demonstrated their credentials by passing the stringent conditions of the new registration test.

The reason I am putting this on the record is that there is a lot of media comment, and comment from people who ought to know better, that the Native Title Tribunal is not working. In fact, it certainly is. Claims that fail the registration test may still continue in mediation. The result of the registration test does not determine whether applicants have native title; it determines only whether they have valuable procedural rights in the period between lodging the application and having it decided.

There are about 150 active future act matters—that is, mining and exploration—before the tribunal. In relation to state regimes, Northern Territory and Queensland are seeking to set up tribunals to deal with future act—that is, mining and exploration matters—leaving the national tribunal to continue mediation and application of the registration test. The next part is very important. Western Australia remains the only state seeking to assume all functions of the National Native Title Tribunal. It has used the federal laws to process future act matters since 1995. South Australia, since 1996, has exercised the option to deal with future act matters through its Environment, Resources and Development Court. In the absence of state regimes, federal laws remain in place to handle future act matters.

I want to place on the record the facts of the matter about the National Native Title Tribunal, because there are many myths that are circulating about its operation. It is operating efficiently, although with more resources it could operate at an even greater level of efficiency. The comment has been made that the Federal Court is a vigorous new player in the process, regardless of state regimes. The court is seeking mediation reports from the tribunal on many claims nationwide with a view to deciding whether they should resume or proceed in mediation or be referred to the court for trial. This shows that we have not a moribund National Native Title Tribunal and process but in fact a very alive, efficient and effective one. The Democrats believe therefore that the only way to progress a solution which will take account of the concerns of all stakeholders is to support the disallowance motion here this afternoon. In doing so, I again seek leave to table the document I presented earlier.
Leave granted.

talk.start.para: —I rise to speak in this debate this afternoon because it is a matter of extreme importance to the Northern Territory, a third of the population which I represent being the indigenous people. The mining and exploration companies up there, in light of today's debate on this issue, also need to be told some truths about the lack of action by the Northern Territory government to resolve this issue.

speech.para: Let me start by giving some background to where we are now. The Commonwealth's Native Title Act, enacted in 1993, empowered the states and territories to establish their own bodies to make determinations of native title, compensation and whether acts attracting the right to negotiate could be done on native title land. To date, only South Australia has established its own native title body. Under the original Native Title Act, native title holders were given the right to negotiate, which applied when certain types of activity were planned on native title land. For example, the right to negotiate applied if a government proposed to grant mining leases on notice land or to compulsorily acquire native title land for the benefit of a third party. There were time limits on the length of negotiation between the native title holders, the grantee party and the government, and if an agreement was not reached within the prescribed time limits then the parties had to go to arbitration and were bound by that decision.

The right to negotiate has attracted support for a number of reasons. It is seen as part of a larger native title right to control access to native title land. The right to negotiate is also regarded as something which makes indigenous people participants in decision making about disruptive activities on their land and which empowers them economically—for example, by providing the means by which they could negotiate profit sharing or employment arrangements with mining companies. Those opposing the right to negotiate argue that it discourages investment and development—which is what we hear from the Northern Territory government—and unfairly gives indigenous peoples rights not possessed by other Australians. But this is not correct. Other Australians have access to a range of legislation which protects their property and land rights, and there should be no differences when it comes to indigenous Australians.

For the most part, the Commonwealth's Native Title Act commenced on 30 September 1998. There is no doubt that this is a long and complex piece of legislation. It also enables state and territory governments to establish legislative schemes which provide exceptions to the right to negotiate on pastoral lease land and certain other types of land such as reserved land, and these regimes can be legislated for under section 43A of the Native Title Act—which we have before us in this disallowance motion. Under such regimes, native title holders must be accorded certain pro cedural rights including the right to be notified of future acts such as mining on their land, the right to object and the right to be consulted—though not the right to negotiate. The act also provides that, if the states and territories legislate under section 43A, then the Commonwealth minister must determine that the legislative scheme satisfies the requirement set out in the act tabled in parliament and the legislation can be disallowed by either house of parliament.

Before I go into some merits of why we have moved this disallowance motion, I want to draw the Senate's attention to exactly what we have before us today. The act clearly talks about the scheme satisfying the requirements set out in the act and being disallowed by either house of parliament. We are dealing here with a Territory government that has been renowned for its use of matters relating to indigenous Territorians at times during their cycle and their terms of government which suit them. Indigenous issues are dangled before the public in the Northern Territory as political puppets and they are trotted out at times when it suits the Territory government.

Today we are dealing with the misinformation and mistruths that are propagated by the Northern Territory government in relation to this issue. I want to show the Senate the kind of stunt that the Northern Territory government stoops to at times in relation to native title and land rights, an area which they love to be able to trot out at election time. I am showing the Senate a copy of a full page ad from the Tennant and District Times of 8 July—which was duplicated around the Territory. How timely on 8 July; just a couple of weeks before a couple of by-elections that we had in the Northern Territory. This is the information it tries to give Territorians. There is not one element of truth in its assertions. It talks about native title laws being the subject of this disallowance motion and it has a go at the now, most competent, Leader of the Opposition in the Territory, Clare Martin, saying she actively supports a system whereby Territorians no longer control their own laws. It says:
She is actively supporting arrangements where an outsider could direct Territorians on how to change their laws.

A stunt; misinformation. The Native Title Act clearly says that any legislation enacted under section 43A must come before either house of this parliament and can be subject to disallowance. So it is not correct to say that Territorians are no longer in control of their laws. It is in fact contempt to refer to the federal parliament as an outsider and a body that can direct Territorians how to change their laws. It is misinformation. It misleads the public in the Northern Territory. But it is something that most of us have got used to when we are dealing with the Northern Territory government and the way that they use indigenous Australians and the issue of native title as nothing more than a political stunt. This is what this is all about.

The policy intention of the Commonwealth government in inserting section 43A into the Native Title Act in July 1998 was no doubt to remove the right to negotiate and thereby diminish the rights and interests of native title holders and their ability to protect their native title, their culture and their way of life. At the time, section 43A was clearly not acceptable to the Central Land Council and the Northern Land Council and neither was it acceptable to all members of the National Indigenous Working Group. Throughout the national native title debate in 1997 and in 1998, the land councils and the National Indigenous Working Group opposed section 43A and advocated a position that all workability issues relating to future acts could be simply, flexibly and equitably resolved through the interaction of the right to negotiate with the indigenous land use agreements.

In addition to the land councils' concerns that section 43A would offer nothing other than diminished rights to Northern Territory native title holders, it is now apparent that section 43A is worse than first envisaged, particularly as state and territory governments can amend their section 43A legislation, once it has passed the initial scrutiny of the Senate, to reduce the right of the native title holders even further. The current Chief Minister, Denis Burke, says, `Don't support this disallowance motion; I know you still have problems with the legislation, but I will fix it up later—trust me.' It is a bit like: `I'm from the government; you can have every faith in what I say.' For how long? 24 hours? A week? Until we get the next Chief Minister? The last couple have been so poor they have been rolled over and rolled out like a piece of pastry.

The Northern Territory government embraced this with enthusiasm and enacted the section 43A legislation prior to the section 43A even coming into operation. Its approach to consultation regarding its proposed section 43A scheme has been extremely poor. In fact, the ability of the Northern Territory government to negotiate properly with Aboriginal people leaves a lot to be desired. During this same period it worked closely with the Commonwealth to develop the scheme beyond its initial legislation to a point where the Attorney-General, as Senator Woodley said, formed a preliminary view that the legislation complied with section 43A way back on 19 February this year. From late February until 27 April the Territory government left all consultation with the land councils to the Commonwealth. Only after the Attorney-General's determination of 27 April, when it realised that Senator Harradine would not support its proposed scheme back then, did the Territory government engage with the land councils in an attempt to win their support. Given the complex legal and policy issues involved, the short period in which discussions took place did not yield an outcome that satisfactorily addressed the land councils' major concerns. I know that Senator Bolkus has sought to table today the eight remaining concerns.

Senator Harradine talked before about the major concerns being fixed. My quick consultation with the people involved indicates that they may be fixable, but they are not fixed; it may be possible to have discussions about the principles around which those outstanding items may well be fixed, but what the Northern Territory government may seek to do at this late hour—as they always seem to want to do when they feel that a deal they have put up in conjunction with their mates in government down here is not working—is to put a proposal on a wing and a prayer, write it on the back of a tram ticket, and hope and believe that some of us in here will be sucked into supporting it. This time it is not going to work. The concerns about the security of the legislation, which I will come back to, have been put before us by Senator Bolkus and Senator Woodley, and there is no security in relation to the Northern Territory government. They have proven time and time again that they are not a government that can be trusted when it comes to dealing with indigenous concerns.

The land councils have said that the proposed schemes will erode the protection currently offered to Northern Territory native title holders under the Native Title Act. They have said that there are eight major shortfalls in the protection offered to native title holders by the Territory legislation. I understand that they are more than willing to sit down and talk about these eight remaining shortfalls, but to say at this time that they have been fixed would be an incorrect statement about the state of play.

The proposed schemes do not provide a realistic or fair process to deal with the large accumulation of mining applications, which, I understand, is around 917 as at 13 May this year, and which has resulted from the Northern Territory government's refusal, as Senator Woodley has placed so correctly on record this afternoon, to utilise the right to negotiate since the Wik decision on 23 December 1996. In sorting out the accumulation of mining applications, the ball is clearly in the Northern Territory government's court. It is up to them, once having received an application, to not simply shelve it in the too-hard basket but to initiate the process by advising the land councils that they have received an application. They have not done that since 1996, and that is why we have a backlog of applications. The land councils lack the resources to deal with the Northern Territory's intended process for dealing with the backlog. I believe this will deny native title holders the ability to protect their rights and interests adequately.

The proposed schemes are likely to lead to the further erosion of the rights of native title holders in the Northern Territory because section 43A fails to provide adequate safeguards against the Northern Territory government's unilateral amendment of its legislation establishing the schemes once the schemes have passed the initial scrutiny of this Senate. It is on this basis that this disallowance motion has been moved. It provides an opportunity for the Northern Territory government to address the outstanding issues. Back on 23 June, when notice of this disallowance motion was given, there was adequate time for the Territory government to approach the land councils and seek to continue—or probably commence in any genuine way—negotiations. I understand that the land councils requested further discussions on 22 June, 19 July and 18 August, and none have occurred.

Let me turn to the two main areas that have been alluded to today: security and the backlog. Given the intention of section 43A to permit state and territory governments to replace the right to negotiate with lesser rights, Territory native title holders find themselves in the unfortunate and ironic position of being concerned that section 43A cannot even secure the best of what can only be a losing situation for native title holders. In the context of the history of relations between the Northern Territory and Aboriginal Territorians, the land councils are concerned that the Northern Territory government will amend its legislation to reduce the rights of native title holders in the future. There have been three different Chief Ministers in the past five years, and each of them has had a different approach to indigenous issues.

It is ironic that this debate today, about genuine consultation with Aboriginal people and their right to be listened to and to have their concerns taken on board, occurs the very day after the report Unlocking the future was tabled in the House of Representatives. It is a report which looks at what has now become commonly known as the Reeves review of the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act 1996.

John Reeves was commissioned at the behest of the Northern Territory government and in consultation with their Liberal mates, so we are now talking about the Territory Liberals and the federal Liberals in cahoots to actually get a review of the land rights act done by John Reeves. But recommendation 1 says it all. It is ironic that we stand here the day after this report was tabled, and I think it sums up quite accurately the actions of the Northern Territory government not just in the last 12 months but in most of the 25 years that they have been in government. This report actually recommends, as stated in recommendation No. 1, the main recommendation, that the land rights act not be amended without traditional Aboriginal owners in the Northern Territory first understanding the nature and purpose of any amendments and as a group giving their consent, and any Aboriginal communities or groups that may be affected having been consulted and given adequate opportunity to express their views. So we have the federal government, in cahoots with the Northern Territory government, wanting to unilaterally review and amend the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act.

A majority report yesterday from the House of Representatives committee, from both sides of parliament, makes some very strong comments about the lack of consultation with Aboriginal people in the Territory and the lack of opportunity for them to be able to understand the nature and purpose of the amendments. Today we have a chance for the Senate to actually scrutinise what is happening with the section 43A legislation under the Native Title Act. You wonder why we would not be suspicious about the genuineness of the Northern Territory never amending this legislation and about not being given the opportunity for the legislation to come back before this federal parliament for further scrutiny.

In relation to the current Territory proposals, it is a matter of grave concern that the Commonwealth minister indicated a preliminary view that the Northern Territory laws as in force on 22 February this year would comply with the requirements of the Native Title Act. If this disallowance motion does not get up today and their scheme under section 43A is approved and goes ahead, there is no doubt that any further amendments will just get the big tick from their mates on the other side of the chamber.

In my few remaining minutes I turn to the issue that I know Denis Burke will hang his hat on in the Territory and that the media no doubt will run with very largely there, and that is the backlog of claims. I will try to dispel some of the myths and misinformation that have been put around about this issue. I have said on record previously that the policy intention of inserting section 43A into the act was to remove the right to negotiate and thereby diminish the rights and interests of native title holders. Section 43A was never about simply providing for state or territory based legislation. That was already provided for by the Native Title Act under section 43, and that provides for a state or territory based right to negotiate process.

The South Australian government intends to continue with its own legislation establishing a section 43 scheme—not a section 43A scheme. New South Wales, Victoria and Tasmania appear content to retain the Commonwealth right to negotiate. It is clear that the Northern Territory government, in developing this scheme, is interested—it should be truthful about this—only in taking away the existing rights of native title holders in the Territory. In May this year there were 917 outstanding mining exploration applications. This situation is the result of the Northern Territory's self-imposed moratorium on mining applications since the Wik decision. The moratorium was self-imposed unnecessarily and arose entirely from the Territory government's refusal to utilise the right to negotiate process under the Native Title Act 1993. That continues to this present day. The bulk of the backlog applications have accumulated in the 2½ years since the Wik decision, and a significant number of applications accumulated prior to Wik.

Since 16 June the land councils have been awaiting data from the Northern Territory government regarding the 548 non-exploration applications that make up more than half of the backlog. This vital information will enable the necessary assessment for the development of a comprehensive strategy to deal with these matters. The Northern Territory government claims that the current Native Title Act cannot deal with the backlog, yet it has never attempted to deal with the mining applications in accordance with the Native Title Act. The only fault with the current Commonwealth right to negotiate is that it can be triggered only by the Northern Territory government issuing a notice under section 29 of the Native Title Act, and the Territory has steadfastly refused to get the process working so that now, nearly three years after Wik, it can say, `Look, the process isn't working, and this is why we need a scheme that takes away the right to negotiate.' Of course, if you scratch the surface a little, you will find that the Northern Territory government has decided that the right to negotiate process was very workable when it wanted to get an agreement about the Alice Springs-Darwin railway. It had no qualms then about triggering the right to negotiate. What happened? An agreement for over 1,400 kilometres of proposed railway happened in approximately six months.

There are many more things I would like to say about this disallowance motion, but my time is very fast running out. I urge the Senate to support this motion by the Labor Party. This is nothing more than an attempt on behalf of the Northern Territory government to further reduce the rights of indigenous Territorians in the Territory and another stunt on their behalf.

talk.start.para: —The effect of the High Court's Wik decision in 1996 was that it extended the right to negotiate procedures of the original 1993 Native Title Act to all land where native title may coexist. The 1998 amendment to the Native Title Act made provision for states and territories to set up alternative land administration schemes for future development over such land. For these alternative provision schemes to operate, the state or territory scheme has to go through a consultation process that has to comply with the national standards set out in the Native Title Act.

speech.para: The issue of what land administration regime is to apply is of particular importance to the Northern Territory. This is because 50 per cent of the Territory comes within the control of the Commonwealth's Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act 1976, 42 per cent of the Territory is Aboriginal land and a further eight per cent is under claim under that act. The land rights act has its own land administration procedures that apply instead of those in the Native Title Act. While the land rights act has been very successful in returning land to Aboriginal Territorians, it has not delivered in regard to promoting indigenous employment or creating development opportunities.

In addition to this 50 per cent under the control of the land rights act, a further 49 per cent of the Territory is pastoral lease land over which there may be coexisting native title. The combined effect of the Commonwealth's land rights act and the Native Title Act is that special restrictive land administration laws apply to over 99 per cent of the Northern Territory. This has retarded development in the Territory and has had a detrimental effect on employment opportunities for Aboriginal Territorians. It is therefore of utmost importance that the Territory has the best possible land administration system for that 49 per cent of the Territory covered by the pastoral estate. It is important for the future of the Territory, it is important for the future of Aboriginal Territorians and ultimately it will be important for the integrity of the Native Title Act.

The Northern Territory applied for three determinations for alternative provision schemes under section 43A of the Native Title Act. They related to the Mining Act, the Petroleum Act and the Land Acquisition Act. The schemes were developed in three stages. The first step was the enactment of legislation to such a stage whereby the Commonwealth Attorney-General had come to a preliminary view that the schemes complied with the requirements of the Native Title Act. Once this stage had been reached, the consultation process with the representative bodies commenced. This resulted in a number a meetings and submissions. As a result of the consultation process, the Northern Territory Legislative Assembly made a number of amendments to its schemes. These amendments addressed compliance issues and workability matters.

Following these amendments, the Attorney-General made the determinations that the Territory schemes complied with the requirements of the Native Title Act. These determinations were dated 27 April 1999. As a result of ongoing discussions with the representative bodies, the Territory made further amendments to its schemes in June 1999. These amendments go above and beyond section 43A compliance and were made in an effort to reach agreement with the representative bodies.

Unfortunately, it was not possible to reach an agreement with the representative bodies and the ALP lodged motions of disallowance against all three schemes on 24 June 1999. At the end of the extensive consultations between the representative bodies and the Northern Territory government, there were three issues standing in the way of an agreement: the content of the legislation, security regarding future amendments to Territory schemes and how to deal with the backlog of exploration and mining applications.

In regard to the content of the legislation, the joint land councils made an initial submission—some 100 pages long and about an inch thick—at the start of the consultation phase. By 22 June the outstanding matters had been reduced to eight relatively insignificant matters. Of these eight issues, the Territory says that its legislative schemes clearly address three and the Commonwealth has said that it will address one.

The remaining issues are as follows. Firstly, the representative bodies say that the requirements in the Territory schemes—that claimants should give particulars of how the proposed development is likely to affect their rights and interests—should be removed. The Territory says these particulars are necessary to allow the consultation process—to minimise the impact of the activity on native title interests—to work. The provision of details will facilitate agreements being reached regarding projects.

Secondly, the representative bodies say that superior courts should be prevented from obtaining access to anthropological material, filed in the Territory's land and mining tribunal, for the purpose of making recommendations regarding development or mining applications. The Northern Territory schemes already make provision for the protection of culturally sensitive material, and the Northern Territory governments says that it is contrary to public policy to have secrecy provisions.

Thirdly, the representative bodies want the removal of a provision requiring those claiming compensation to give notice of the claim within three years. The Territory's response is that this provision applies to all those with an interest in land, can be complied with simply by sending in a one-line letter and is necessary to allow for orderly land administration. In any event, there is a procedure for extending the time period by applying to the land and mining tribunal. Fourthly, and finally, in some circumstances the representative bodies say that compensation should be paid without proof of native title. This proposal has already been fully considered and debated in this chamber; it is clearly untenable.

The significance and merits of these outstanding legislative issues need to be considered in the context of the schemes in their entirety and in the context of the concessions and accommodations made to date. I am informed that there were three months of consultation on this Territory legislation with the land councils before this disallowance motion and that from August 1998 there were four or five specific invitations to the NLC and the CLC—from the NT government to discuss these issues—which were not responded to.

Any reasonable assessment would have to conclude that these outstanding legislative issues are of little consequence. That leaves the issue of security regarding future amendments and the backlog of outstanding mining applications. It is important that the security issue is clearly understood. The Native Title Act sets out the national standards that state and Territory alternative provision schemes have to comply with. There is in-built security in the Native Title Act, which sets out the process for reviewing and revoking determinations if a state or Territory scheme is amend ed at any stage in the future so that it falls below the specified requirements.

Nine-tenths of the Territory schemes are reviewable under the process set out in section 43A(9) of the Native Title Act. It is only those enhancements made to the scheme which go above and beyond the Native Title Act requirements that are at issue. Notwithstanding the fact that the issue involves only future amendments above the national standards set by this parliament, the Northern Territory has proposed a scheme to deal with these concerns. It involves the passing of legislation at the next sittings of the Legislative Assembly requiring consultation with the representative bodies prior to any amendment to section 43A; agreeing to allow at least two months between the introduction of any amendment bill and debate; consultation with representative bodies with a view to reaching agreement concerning the form of the amendments; and providing a draft bill and reasons for amendment prior to introduction.

The Northern Territory has no intention of making any amendments to its schemes. However, it has to be recognised that unforeseen circumstances and workability issues arise over the passage of time. That is the reason that parliaments have the capacity to make amendments. The Territory's proposals will make the procedure for any amendment as open and transparent as possible.

It has been suggested that one way of dealing with this security issue is to abandon the section 43A schemes and place them in an indigenous land use agreement—an ILUA. The ILUA proposal is fundamentally flawed. It is contrary to public policy and probably illegal. It would require the current Territory government to delegate legislative authority and fetter the discretion of future Territory parliaments. Given that these schemes can only operate on coexisting land, the ILUA proposal would split land administration procedures into multiple layers: one legislative layer for non-native title issues, and a private agreement for native title procedures. We are talking about land administration procedures for 49 per cent of the Northern Territory, not some discrete area where the native title holders are known. The concept of an indigenous land use agreement is simply not viable in these circumstances.

It seems to me that the Territory is being punished for enhancing its legislation beyond the standards set out in the Native Title Act. If you follow the arguments of those proposing an ILUA through to their natural conclusion, the Territory would have been better off if it had stuck to the schemes as determined by the Attorney-General and had not tried to address the concerns raised by the indigenous representatives. That just cannot be right.

If there is a genuine problem here—and I say there is not—then the issue is one for the federal parliament. It is up to this parliament to amend the national standards that it requires state and territory schemes to comply with. It offends parliamentary propriety to set legislative standards, have a jurisdiction comply with those standards, and for this chamber to then say that compliance with the standards we set is not the basis upon which state and territory schemes will be assessed. The Northern Territory Chief Minister has said that he is prepared to undertake not to amend the Territory section 43A schemes for at least a year to allow the federal parliament to make up its mind as to additional arrangements regarding future amendments of state and territory schemes and to make the appropriate changes to the Commonwealth act.

The security issue is not a problem of the Northern Territory's making. There is already in-built security in the Native Title Act to ensure state and territory schemes do not get amended to fall below the standards set out in the federal act. The Territory has offered to do all that it legislatively can to address the concerns raised. The security issue is not a valid reason for disallowing the Territory's schemes.

That leaves the issue of outstanding exploration and mining applications. There are currently some 917 outstanding applications. Because many of these are by the same company in the same locality, a number of applications can be grouped together and dealt with at the same time. This will result in there being about 300 applications to be dealt with. Let me make this clear. These applications have to be dealt with either under the Territory's alternative provision schemes or under the right to negotiate scheme. Under either procedure the representative bodies are funded to represent claimants. There is no additional cost to representative bodies that arises from the Territory schemes. The multimillion dollar claims by the land councils are a complete furphy. The claims are without foundation. In fact, under the Territory schemes, the Territory has offered an orderly and staggered approach to dealing with the backlog. This measured approach would assist in keeping work levels fairly even and would greatly assist resourcing and funding requirements.

The Territory has made a reasonable and balanced offer as to how to deal with the backlog if the Territory schemes are allowed to operate. These include: a two-month period to allow representative bodies to get prepared—this would be on top of the statutory four-month period for lodging objections; limiting backlog applications to two per week per representative body for exploration applications; provision of a schedule showing which applications would be dealt with and when; and joint development of standard term agreements that protect indigenous interests.

The consequence of disallowance will be that all outstanding and all future development applications will be forced back into the already overloaded and stressed right to negotiate process—a process that is having difficulty keeping up with the influx of applications and difficulty in producing timely and cost-efficient results. Excluding expedited procedure matters, it is understood that there are currently over 6,000 development applications outstanding, with the numbers now rising by about 3,000 per year. Since 1993 there have been just under 500 agreements and only a handful of tribunal determinations.

The signs are on the wall in big letters. The right to negotiate is a system heading for trouble. It is a system that was simply not designed to cope with the added pressure of coexisting land. The relief valve was to be state and territory alternative provisions. If these alternative schemes are not allowed to operate, the right to negotiate procedures of the Native Title Act are going to need major amendment in the very near future. That is the choice facing the Senate. Some of you may recall the national angst the last time major amendments were necessary.

It has been suggested that the Territory's schemes would only proceed if the Territory had been able to obtain the consent of the representative bodies. The Northern Territory engaged in an extensive process of negotiations with the representative bodies, with a view to reaching agreement. For a variety of reasons, most of them having nothing to do with the Territory or its schemes, it was not possible to reach an agreement. In regard to this suggestion I simply make the observation that the consent of a body with a vested interest is unlikely to be a valid substitute for an objective appraisal of the Territory's schemes. The Northern Territory government made a real effort to resolve all indigenous concerns. We submit that our schemes do address all issues of substance.

The Northern Territory schemes comply with every requirement set out in the federal legislation. The Northern Territory schemes will produce better results, deliver more to Aboriginal Territorians, be better for the future of the Territory and ultimately be better for the nation. The Northern Territory schemes give appropriate recognition to indigenous interests and yet allow land administration to be left in the hands of the appropriate level of government. Disallowance will shatter attempts to build better relationships. Those of you who vote for disallowance will be directly responsible for this and will bear responsibility to the nation for the costs and delays caused by an overloaded right to negotiate process.

I urge the Senate to endorse a new beginning, a fresh start, to the imposing task of addressing Aboriginal disadvantage and generating indigenous employment. The Northern Territory schemes are reasonable and balanced. They more than comply with the requirements of the Native Title Act and they should be given the chance to work. An example of this community and commercial frustration is the strong representation I received from the Extractive Industry Associa tion of the Northern Territory. I quote from their recent letter:

The Extractive Industry supplied all sand, gravel, soil and rock for the construction of houses and other buildings, road-making, gardening, landscaping and landfill. This includes material for manufacturing concrete, blocks and bricks, plaster, pavers, road base, road surfacing, etc.
The loss of land access to supply these raw materials will result in a virtual shutdown of all industry in the Territory. Alternative supply options would prove unacceptable due to the cost.

Senator Crossin, federal member Warren Snowdon and their Labor mates in Canberra now have to explain to the people of the Territory why they have once again held up jobs and development in the Northern Territory. Senator Bolkus, the Labor meddler from South Australia, has destroyed native title legislation that was fair and workable and which gave a chance for Territorians—both Aboriginal and non-Aboriginal—to work together and progress development and jobs.

The Northern Territory programs were worked out with Northern Territory Aboriginal councils. Senator Bolkus now proposes, because he thinks he has the right, to negotiate exclusively with land councils and the Northern Territory branch of the ALP. Senator Bolkus is being very hypocritical in the way he has approached this. He is doing deals in Queensland with the premier. Let me quote from radio 4QR—

talk.start.para: —Order! You will have to withdraw that comment about Senator Bolkus.
—I withdraw the comment. At 4 p.m. on radio 4QR in Brisbane today, the newsreader said:

speech.para: Mr Beattie says the Queensland legislation won't face the same fate due to an agreement with officials in Kim Beazley's office.
And a quote from Mr Beattie:
They're not going to support a disallowance of a negotiated and sensible outcome for native title in this state.

So we are seeing a backroom deal being done between a Labor premier and Senator Bolkus on an issue that relates to this motion. It is absolutely deplorable that Senator Crossin, in particular, will once again support a move that overturns a bill of the Northern Territory parliament. Her Labor colleagues in the Northern Territory supported this legislation as it went through the Northern Territory parliament. In this place, Senator Crossin takes a different stance. First she attempted to compromise law and order in the Territory by trying to overturn mandatory sentencing, and now she is compromising jobs for Territory constituents, including Aboriginal people, with her disloyalty. This important matter today is about jobs, investment, confidence and giving rights to Aboriginal people for their future and their development. Sadly, this disallowance motion will cause havoc to Aboriginal Territorians.

talk.start.para: —I certainly pay tribute to that contribution by my colleague Senator Tambling. It made eminent sense to me. The Northern Territory's native title regime fulfils all the requirements called for in section 43A of the Commonwealth Native Title Act. It is well known on our side of politics that the Attorney-General is no easy touch on such things, and he has given the Northern Territory regime a tick.

speech.para: Section 43A says that a state or territory regime complies if they contain appropriate procedures for notifying native title claimants, body corporates and other representatives; provide a right to object to a proposed act so far as it affects their registered native title rights and interests; provide for consultation about ways of `minimising the act's impact on registered native title rights and interests'; provide for objections `to be heard by an independent person or body'; and `provide for judicial review of the decision to do the act'. It makes the independent body ruling binding, except for the limited circumstances where the state minister for indigenous affairs must still be consulted and if it is in the interests of the state or territory overall. The state or territory regime must confer rights on claimants that are not less favourable than if they held ordinary title to the land and waters concerned.

There are also requirements as to compensation in subsection (7). Those requirements are that areas of significance must be preserved. The Commonwealth Attorney-General has examined the Northern Territory's alternative provisions, consulted with indigenous bodies and been satisfied that the provisions comply with subsections (4) and (6) and that the requirements of subsection (7) are totally complied with.

The federal government's part in this process began in March 1999. The Attorney-General announced that he had written to various land councils seeking submissions on the Northern Territory's request for three separate section 43A determinations for future acts covered by their mining, lands acquisition and petroleum legislation. The Northern Territory system contains requirements to notify of intent to develop, right to object and a consultation process, where agreements between the parties cannot be reached and the matter is referred to an independent body—that is, the land and mining tribunal. This tribunal's decisions are binding on the government, except in the limited areas requiring consultation with the minister for Aboriginal affairs and involving the interests of the whole of the Territory.

The Northern Territory regime follows the template laid down by the parliament in the Native Title Act, and it has met every provision. I refer the Senate to section 43A, subsection (9), which deals with the revocation of such a determination, as made by the Attorney-General. This subsection provides that, if at any time the alternative provisions are amended—so if the state government amends those provisions—so that they no longer comply, the Commonwealth minister must revoke the determination. A state or territory regime must always meet the set national standards of the Attorney-General, or he can revoke the determination. If future amendments by the state or territory government jeopardise those standards, then the Commonwealth government still retains the power to enforce them. The federal act protects the national standards at all times.

When a state wishes to go further than those standards and to include features which go above and beyond the national standards, the Senate has a once only opportunity to review them, as we are today. The Democrats and the Labor Party want the right to review not only the national standards but also the enhanced features of the state or territory regime. This, effectively, would transfer land administration from the states and territories to the Senate. That is not what the Senate is here to do. It is inappropriate; it is centralisation of the political power and states rights. We have to ask ourselves: what else is going to be caught up in this net—state legislation on heritage sites, and so on?
In the second reading speech on the Native Title Amendment Bill 1997, the Attorney-General said that the bill was designed to achieve several outcomes, the first of which was:

. . . to provide an application and determination system which is constitutionally secure and which will enable the States and Territories to develop their own systems for dealing with native title matters provided they comply with national standards.

Labor is trying to rewrite the national standards so that a whole range of other state matters will have to get the nod from the Senate. On 7 July last year, during the native title debate on state regimes, Senator Minchin commented:

. . . this Commonwealth parliament basically has no experience in, expertise in or familiarity with the property law of this country because it does not deal with it. That is the sovereign right of state parliaments. By virtue of the races power and native title decisions, all of a sudden we have quite massive intervention in property law by the Commonwealth parliament, and there is not that much familiarity with it. The fact is that these are the sorts of procedures laid down, and they have probably been there for 100 years at state level.

He also made it clear that, whoever makes the decision, the act shall be subject to judicial review. So there are many in-built protection measures that relate to the state alternative provisions on native title—the Senate can disallow it, the Attorney-General can revoke it, and the Supreme Court can review it.

It is not necessary or in the interests of good government for the Senate to double-dip and to control every decision-making process impinging on native title in this country. The effect on the Senate of disallowing state regimes is to force a return to the slow and costly right-to-negotiate process. Rural and regional areas need job creating projects. The right to negotiate does not deliver them; it obstructs them. There are currently some 6,029 development applications awaiting resolution of the right-to-negotiate process. Every year there are another 3,000 or so. After four years, we have seen some 500 determinations, and that is all. They are coming in faster than they are going out.

There is a lot of talk these days about mutual obligation. The Senate has an obligation to let the states get on with handling native title in their own way, provided minimum standards are met. We have to help the states and territories pursue jobs in industry, especially in rural and regional areas. Sentencing them to return to the logjam of the right to negotiate process is not the way to get any of those developments moving.
