The truth is that Labor are upset at having been dealt out of the game on the big issues of the day, so they are weighing in for all they are worth on this one. The great pity about it all is that, by doing so, Labor have reignited the bush against native title. Just when national progress was being made on reconciliation, Labor have to lay a political dead cat on the table. Just as there was positive momentum on indigenous issues, Labor spat in the eyes of land owners under claim and job creating investors. I can tell you that the mood of the bush has turned overnight on this issue. After all the years of native title debate, and the agony that both sides went through trying to reach some sort of agreement in the process, after all the compromises, the Labor Party want to rub salt into the wounds and get everyone upset again.

My phone has been ringing about this issue today, and I can tell you the kinds of responses my office has been getting. This morning a person rang me and said, `It would have been kinder to tell us all to go at the beginning of the native title debate.' That is what one landowner said, and nothing now has changed.

talk.start.para: —The Senate is facing a situation which, if goodwill prevails on all sides, can be satisfactorily resolved in the interests of all of the stakeholders and all of those where native title coexists with other land interests. The Senate is debating a disallowance motion on the Northern Territory alternative provisions determinations.

speech.para: Let me go back to the response of the government to Wik. As honourable senators will know, that response came before this parliament in 1997. It was defeated by the Senate late in that year on my vote. When the matter again came before the Senate in 1998, there was a huge build-up. There were negotiations conducted with the government. There were something like 220-odd amendments to the legislation.

One of those amendments was section 43A. The purpose of section 43A was to allow states and territories to establish alternative provisions which would be able to be delivered to the indigenous people and others with interests in the area. Because these schemes would be owned by the state or the territory, they would have an interest in ensuring the success of these schemes. I insisted that it would be desirable—and, in fact, constitutionally correct—for the state or territory legislation to be referred to the Attorney-General and for the Attorney-General to make a determination with respect to those schemes. I also insisted that that determination be subject to disallowance by the federal parliament. In other words, the parliament would be obliged to exercise its rights—in fact, its duties—under the Aboriginal affairs powers of the Constitution. On the other hand, of course, the states would own the schemes because of their responsibility for land management. It is because I so insisted that this matter is here before us today. I am surprised, frankly, that Senator Bolkus is not up to steam on what has been happening.

I also insisted upon a number of other matters with respect to the sunset clause. There is no sunset clause. The government was proposing a sunset clause. I ensured that the registration tests were extended to cover the stolen generation and the victims of the locked gates. I insisted that the legislation be subject to the Racial Discrimination Act. All of that, bear in mind, when it went through the parliament avoided a bitter race based election.

talk.start.para: —You wouldn't have been game.

—`Wouldn't have been game,' says Senator Bolkus. One Nation actually got, I think, 54 per cent in one particular seat in Queensland. The fact that I did avoid a race based election may have resulted in One Nation giving Senator Brown and the Labor Party preferences before me at the last election.
—I wasn't even standing.
—I am sorry—the Greens. You are right, Senator Brown, it was not you. It was Senator Brown's party—the Greens.

speech.para: Let us come now to the Northern Territory scheme. I suppose you could say that this scheme has had a chequered history. Mark I of the scheme was legislated in the Northern Territory on 19 August 1998, Mark II was legislated on 1 October 1998, and there were further amendments. In fact, the scheme at the present moment is Mark VII. But let me make it perfectly clear who it was who proposed to move the first disallowance of the Northern Territory scheme. It was I.

talk.start.para: —You were prepared to move this one, too, but you didn't.

—Don't fret; I am supporting this one. When I did that, things started to move, and the parties were called together under my auspices. I must say that a great deal is owed to my legal advisers, Messrs McCarthy QC and Kildea, who are experts on native title. It was in their chambers that the first substantive discussions took place between the land councils, the Northern Territory government, ATSIC and other stakeholders.

speech.para: The current provisions are said to be above the minima. So what concerns the land councils and, indeed, ATSIC most is how to secure the advantages that have been gained in the development of alternative state and territory schemes and how to make sure that those advantages are preserved against any state or territory introducing and passing legislation which will reduce those particular benefits down to the minima as required in the act. That is a matter which I addressed to Mr Burke last week. To give Mr Burke his credit, he was prepared to agree to such a scheme and to agree to legislation going through this parliament to ensure that occurred. That is point one. So the major issue of security can be fixed.

talk.start.para: —It is not fixed.
—There are other people involved—not yourself—
—Where is it fixed?

—There are various ways that this can be done. Things can be changed, legislation can go through this place. If this passes, recision motions can be carried by the Senate if other things are in place. There are a few things to go yet.
—Nothing is fixed. That is right.
—I have not seen Senator Bolkus being interested enough to attempt to get some sort of resolution of this matter.
—We talked about this six weeks ago.
—Order! Senator Bolkus, there is too much cross-chamber discussion.

—Senator Bolkus then tabled eight points from the land councils. The fact is the Northern Territory government is not prepared to die in a ditch on those particular points. They are not critical points.

speech.para: The question of the backlog is the third matter of the land councils. That is a matter which has been discussed, and there is a recognition that that needs to be determined properly so that the backlog can be attended to by well resourced representative groups.

I understand the concern of the land councils about the need to get all of this into place before the matter is finally resolved. I also acknowledge that it is important sometimes to get the burner going and to have a situation where people's minds are focused. It is clear that the minds of the various parties are focused at the present moment, and I acknowledge now that there is a need for a little bit of time for these matters to be resolved, but there are ways of allowing the situation to proceed.

I acknowledge the statement by Senator Woodley. I listened carefully to Senator Woodley. He indicated that indigenous land use agreements were an important factor, and I acknowledge that as well, but might I be permitted to observe that they were part of the Native Title Amendment Bill—
Senator Woodley interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Thank you. Yes, I would have loved the Democrats to have voted for them at the time. They are working and they have their place. Quite clearly, however, the Labor Premier of Queensland feels that it is not appropriate, as some federal Labor members are saying, that Queensland can fix their problem with an ILUA. Clearly these members do not know about section 24DJ of the Native Title Act. Appeals under that section would take forever to resolve, to the detriment of the Queensland people—Aboriginal and non-Aboriginal.

speech.para: The Queensland Premier and his government have spent much time developing their section 43A, and I do acknowledge that the 43A system is regarded, politically, as a desirable measure, because it is owned by the states and the territories, provided that the Commonwealth parliament is able to exercise its responsibilities under the race powers of the Constitution. And that is the essence of the matter.

I am not going to support the Northern Territory legislation without there being a procedure whereby the Commonwealth parliament exercises its proper authority and duty in respect of Aboriginal people. As you would all know, there is a way to go yet, but the legislation giving effect to that need can be passed through this parliament quite quickly, and other matters can be settled quite quickly. I agree with the land councils that it does need a little bit of time, but we have a situation now where matters can be resolved relatively quickly.

This parliament stands ready, I believe, to see and enact legislation which will have the effect of ensuring that amendments to state based schemes are looked over by the federal parliament. You might say, `They have to come to the Attorney-General. Isn't that sufficient for the purposes of the Commonwealth's duty in regard to Aboriginal people?' I would say no, because the Attorney-General need only determine the matter on what he or she considers to be the minimum. I think it is important for the parliament itself to have that responsibility. I am sure the parliament will exercise that responsibility in a reasonable and proper fashion, so far as the Queensland legislation is concerned and so far as the Northern Territory legislation is concerned, if those eight points can be resolved. That is why I started off my contribution urging goodwill on all sides.

I do not know Mr Burke as well as others do, but I have a strong impression that he wants to have a new deal so that he can enter into a more cooperative framework for discussions with the stakeholders than has been the case previously. Mr Gatjil Djerrkura, the Chairman of ATSIC, did say to me that yes, the security matter was the major issue. He said that there should not be any `midnight takeaway legislation'. I will be supporting the disallowance motion to enable the framework to come before this parliament quickly so that there will not be any such midnight takeaways, if any state or territory be so inclined.

talk.start.para: —Before I speak to this disallowance motion, I would like to bring to the Senate's notice that I do have mining interests. I would like to address a few of the issues raised by senators in this debate. Senator Bolkus raised the issue of the impact of native title on the indigenous people of the Northern Territory. I would also like to raise the issue that it equally impacts on non-indigenous people of the Northern Territory. I believe there are processes that will eventually address all of those problems. Senator Bolkus then went on to say that the Senate needs `to send a clear message to the other states'. Is Senator Bolkus saying that we are no longer addressing the virtues of this legislation? Are we now using this opportunity to show to the states that they are going to have to comply with another section of the act? `Don't bother about putting up state alternative processes under section 43; just comply with the rest of the act.'

speech.para: Senator Hill spoke briefly about the time lines in the Northern Territory process and he indicated that they are similar to those in the Commonwealth legislation, as is the right to negotiate. There is a willingness on the part of traditional owners in the areas to come to agreement on these issues. I am fearful that the agreements that are brought about in the negotiations between the miners and the traditional owners will be subverted by either legal process or the political process.

Senator Woodley said that clearly the input of traditional owners may not be recognised and that the issues and the ideals of this Senate should prevail. I believe that that is in total contrast to the spirit of this legislation. If the spirit of the legislation is not to protect the cultural heritage of the indigenous people as those indigenous people see it, who are we to be judging on their behalf?

Senator Woodley went on further to say that he gave great credence to and recognised the input of the land councils and, similar to Senator Bolkus, tabled documents pertaining to that. I would like to put to Senator Woodley: where is the balance in the assessment of the Democrats of this legislation? Where is the input from the mining industry that he took into consideration prior to making the determinations that he put here today? I ask Senator Woodley to table those documents and that input.

Senator Crossin raised the issue of direction coming from outside the Territory, not only for this legislation but also for the Commonwealth act. Would the Senate like to consider the input of Erica Irine Days, a permanent secretary to the indigenous working group with the UN? Is the Senate prepared to acknowledge her input into the development of the legislation? Is it willing to accept the input of Alfonse Martineze, the chairman of a United Nations working group whose specific task is to look at treaties made between nations and states? We do have influ ence on legislation and documentation and input into these from outside the Northern Territory, but we need to look at that in a balanced way.

There are other documents I could refer to, such as A good idea waiting to happen, and I could consider the influence that that will ultimately have, not only on this chamber but also on indigenous issues throughout Australia. In the document that Senator Bolkus tabled today, reference is made to the nature of the objection and the fact that traditional owners have no other recourse than to apply for a native title determination to be part of the requirements of these acts. In actuality, this is because of the Commonwealth legislation itself. I put it to the Senate: how can a mining company progress an agreement unless it is sure whom it is talking to? How can you have a consultative process when you have no surety that the person you are consulting is the correct person? The problem raised in the document of the nature of objection is a function of the act that this parliament has actually produced.

Senator Bolkus went on to talk about time lines and the fact that the clock has started running. I would draw the Senate's attention to the inordinate delays in the processing of claims by government and the NNTT. There needs to be a clock running. The document further talked about agreements. There are other processes within the Commonwealth legislation for progressing indigenous land use agreements, and it will be very interesting to see the development of these throughout Australia.

In the document that Senator Woodley tabled today, there was reference to the Miriuwong-Gajerrong case that sits between the Northern Territory and Western Australia. There was, again, very interesting input into that decision by Justice Lee. If we need to look at who is having input, let us look at the Canadian precedents that were used by Justice Lee in that determination: the Sparrow case, Badger, Gladston, Adams, Cote and Van der Peet. These were all Canadian determinations in the Canadian High Court that are influencing decisions in courts in this country. It is also worth while noting that in Canada the traditional owners in that Commonwealth do have rights to mineral resources. Therefore, there would be direct conflict in using those determinations in Australia, where the Australian Commonwealth clearly reserves the rights of minerals to the Commonwealth.

There are many other issues that we need to assess during the discussion on this disallowance motion. We need to look at the costs. Senator Tambling brought up the costs involved in this process. In Queensland the Northern Land Council responded to 18 section 29 notices at a cost of over $150,000. The land councils themselves clearly indicate they cannot sustain the costs involved following the process of the 1993 Commonwealth Native Title Act. The land councils themselves clearly say they require alternative processes. The state alternative processes—section 43A—are the vehicle that will attain that. With the correct consultation with the land councils and the state governments, this is how this can be achieved.

Again, in relation to those applications and the responses to those section 29 notices, some are over an area of one hectare. The traditional owners, through their land council, are responding to those claims over one hectare of land, which, when the resulting mining tenures are granted, clearly indicates that the native title issues, their heritage, have been addressed. They have no option other than to continue that application for a native title determination all the way through the High Court, with enormous expense to the Australian taxpayer and to the land council involved, to attain something they already have when the mining lease is granted. Yes, there is a need for state alternative processes.

Senator Harradine himself, in the chamber, just before me, stated that the conditions in the Northern Territory proposals actually exceed the requirement of the Commonwealth legislation, and then proceeded to say that he is still going to vote against the motion. Is he assessing this disallowance motion on the merits of the legislation? I do not believe he is.

We need to look at the issue as to whether the state has consulted with the traditional owners and the land councils. We also need to take note that land management is a state responsibility. It is the requirement of the states to manage their land use. We need to realise that and accept that. We need to look at another issue, substantial impact. What is substantial impact? Why are we disallowing these state proposals? Is it because of substantial impact? Has anybody defined substantial impact here today? I do not believe they have.

My concern is for the future generations of children and also for the work force in the Northern Territory—not only of indigenous people but also of non-indigenous people. We need to assess this legislation on its merit, not play politics. We need to look for a process that will give security to the traditional owners. We need to look to a process that will give security for mining. I sincerely believe that the state alternative processes do move in the right direction for achieving that.

talk.start.para: —I agree that we need a process that is going to lead to security for all. The problem here is that, because of hasty action to try to cobble together an agreement which would get through the Native Title Amendment Bill last year, there was not proper regard given to the consequences, and so here we are in this position of having to disallow Northern Territory legislation which does not adequately reflect the intention of this place, the parliament, at that time.

speech.para: My colleague of last year, Senator Dee Margetts from Western Australia, put forward a motion at the outset of the debate then that, because there had been insufficient consultation and negotiation with Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people regarding changes to the Native Title Act 1993 and the entire issue of indigenous land justice, the bill at that time should have been withdrawn until a comprehensive process of negotiation and agreement with the many indigenous communities of the continent had taken place. Had the other components of the Senate heeded that move by then Senator Margetts, we would not be in this situation. I remember clearly the rapid moves to amend the legislation as it was before the Senate and the insertion of subclause 43A. In my speech in the second reading debate, I had this to say:

Senator Harradine said last night that this is an occasion which will not come again—`If we don't get it right, I cannot foresee a future time when we will get it right.' How wrong he is—because we are not getting it right here, and it is going to continue to trouble us, and we are going to have to get it right further down the line.

Here we are a year later trying to get it right. There were amendments being hastily cobbled together by Senator Harradine and Senator Colston and the government last year, and they did not pay sufficient regard to the concerns of many players, but in particular the concerns of the indigenous people of this country. But it is good to hear Senator Harradine now acceding to the numbers in the place, which mean that the Northern Territory legislation will be disallowed by the Senate, and recognising that there is going to be a need for legislation to come back in here to fix up the hole in amendment 43A which he put before the parliament a year ago. He quite rightly says it is because I insisted on this amendment, 43A, that the scheme is up before the Senate today. But the problem is that we ought to have a watertight right for indigenous people to negotiate over their lands in the Native Title Act. It should be nationally guaranteed. Instead of that, the Harradine-government process, the Harradine-Howard process, was to devolve that right—and the formulation of it, or the handling of it essentially—as a template in the bill, to the states and territories.

It was quite clear that this would lead to an effort to minimise the rights of the indigenous people and to advantage others. We as a parliament ought not to have allowed that process to occur, but we did because the numbers were with Senator Harradine and Senator Colston at the time. We are now here charged with a responsibility to fix it up. I notice that Senator Harradine said that the first substantial negotiations took place with the Northern Territory land councils on the Northern Territory legislation in chambers at his arrangement. That bespoke the failure up until that time of the Northern Territory authorities to have negotiated with the Territory participants, in particular the land councils. So Senator Harradine was acquainted with that some months ago. He said:
. . . I acknowledge now that there is a need for a little bit of time now for these matters to be resolved, . . .

The problem is that that little bit of time was not granted to this chamber a year ago. When it was not granted, we were effectively being denied the wish of the Greens at that time in particular, as expressed by Senator Margetts, that there be adequate consultation with the indigenous stakeholders. I am supporting this disallowance very strongly. It is leverage for indigenous people to stop the erosion of justice for them. It is some leverage to enable them to be given the negotiating rights over the legislation, let alone their lands, that was owed them by the Northern Territory authorities in the first place. And it is a warning to other state and territory jurisdictions that, at least as the Senate is configured at the moment, they are not going to be able to pull the rug from under the very limited indigenous rights that ended up being in the Native Title Act.

If we look at the proposed declaration on the rights of indigenous people, which is making very slow progress through the United Nations—but at least it has world authorities behind it supporting those universal rights—and move to article 26 on ownership, amongst other things, it states:
Indigenous peoples have the right to own and control the use of their land, waters and other resources.

That is basic. We are a long way, in this debate taking place today, from accepting that as basic, just as we were a long way from accepting that as basic when the debate took place on the Native Title Bill more than 12 months ago. Article 30 of the draft declaration on the rights of indigenous people says: Indigenous peoples have the right to determine strategies for the development of their land and resources.
It goes on to say:
Governments must obtain the consent of indigenous peoples before giving approval to activities affecting their land resources, particularly the development of mineral, water and other resources.

Whether or not a declaration of such rights ever gets to being—and one has to be cautious about being optimistic on the matter because of the enormous sway that international corporations particularly have over the evolution of such humanitarian ideals or, I might say, such ideals of basic human and civil rights—there is inculcated into that draft a principle which should be guiding our deliberations.

Last year the parliament passed legislation which infringes those basic rights and which cut the ground from under these principles which are self-evident. That being so, we have here not just the opportunity but the responsibility to see that the ground is not cut even further by state and territory administrations against the interests of indigenous people. I am very pleased to be supporting this motion because hopefully it is going to ensure that at least we will not have the awful circumstance in which a Northern Territory ordinance, bill or act gets approval in this place and the next day or late the next night the Territory authorities change it and we are left devoid of the power and ability to redress a perfidious act like that.

It is extraordinarily important that the Senate have this right. It is a little redress to the handing away of rights to establish national benchmarks for all indigenous people in this situation, that handing away having occurred in the vote by the government and the two Independent senators last year. I support the disallowance motion from the Labor Party and I look forward to seeing that this one fault amongst many in the Native Title Act is corrected.

talk.start.para: —I rise to speak on this disallowance motion and state clearly and categorically that I think this disallowance motion is a total miscarriage of the purpose of the Senate and what it is about. It is a straight intrusion into the rights and capacity of the Northern Territory government to carry out what its process should be and, extending it further, into the rights and proper process of the states' constitutional rights in managing land, whether it be in terms of the native title legislation, whether it be for mining or for farming, whether it be in our cities, or wherever it might be.

speech.para: This process that the Senate is now involved in, where it thinks it has a power that is greater, in my view, than the Constitution, is absolutely and totally wrong; and it has the potential to do long-term damage to this nation of ours and, more importantly, to bring this chamber into total disrespect with the people out on the ground. As regards the current proposal before us concerning the Northern Territory, we are thousands of miles from where the action occurs, and we are trying to dictate to the Northern Territory how they should run their own affairs and how they should deal with this question of land management through the Native Title Act.

In the position adopted at the time the 10-point plan was before us in the legislation—which ended up being a nine-point plan—many of us found it very difficult to accept this proposition before us. The extension of the debate in yesterday's newspapers to further amendments to the Native Title Act to further restrict the rights of the states must be fought at all cost. It will make it almost impossible for the states and territories to manage their land in an appropriate and proper manner. It is an issue that is not in the best interests of resource development, the creation of jobs in this nation or the conservation requirements of land management and landcare. I do not care what angle you look at it from, but the more we intrude into this area, the worse the job that will be done in these matters.

This is not just about native title. We have seen in the resource security legislation for the RFAs an attempt to make RFAs a disallowable instrument in this chamber. Once again that is very clearly a task that was set out by our forefathers in the Constitution as being for the states. I challenge the advocates of what is happening now. That this Senate has the right to override an agreement signed by the Prime Minister and a Premier is totally out of order and is something that will do enormous damage to what Australia is about and what it stands for.

One could talk for a long time about this matter and certain aspects of it. I do not have the time tonight to do that, but I want to record quite clearly my very strong objection to the process that is going on now. In the short term it is going to be detrimental in a range of areas, including the management of land, resources and the environment, right through the Commonwealth of Australia. It is about time this Senate woke up to what it is doing. I would suggest that, if you put this issue to a referendum of the Australian people right now, you would get your pants thrashed off because it would not be acceptable to the community out there. We are seeing a situation where this Senate is trying to usurp a power that should remain with the states. I cannot say it any stronger than that, other than to express my disappointment that the Northern Territory government, which has put a lot of effort into putting together their state regime—which is allowed under the native title legislation—will now almost certainly be subject to a disallowance motion in this chamber. That will cost all Northern Territory people jobs and it will be detrimental to Aboriginal people.

talk.start.para: —in reply—I indicate that I will not be speaking at length, but a lot has been said in this debate that needs replying to. I will reply to a couple of points and make a couple of extra ones. We have heard a lot of extraordinary contributions in this parliament from time to time, but the last one from Senator Crane has to take the cake. He says that, because a state Premier or territory Chief Minister and the Prime Minister come to an agreement, then the national parliament of the country has no right to involve itself. Don't you know about the rule of law, for a start? Don't you know that people in parliaments, wherever they are, have to act in accordance with the law? The law governs relations between governments and individuals and governments and governments. In this case we have a law of this parliament—the Native Title Act, as amended 1998, section 43A of which gives us specific and ongoing responsibility to do exactly what we are doing today; and no Prime Minister and no Premier can get together in a backroom deal and override the legislation passed in this parliament. If you contend that seriously, then you may as well contend that the rule of law is no longer relevant in this country. It was a fly-by-night, bunkum contribution by Senator Crane, which does neither him nor the government any credit.

speech.para: Another point that needs to be made is in respect of backlog. Crocodile tears are shed by Senator Tambling and Senator Hill about the backlog under the right to negotiate provisions in the Northern Territory—that some 917 applications are current. What they do not admit is the truth of the situation. There is no backlog; it is just that no-one is allowed to get on the track. There is no hold-up in applications; those applications are not even allowed into the system. Why not? Because the Territory government has put a moratorium on the processing of claims under the Native Title Act. You cannot get into a backlog situation when you cannot even get into the game. For three years they have been saying, `We don't accept the Native Title Act; therefore, we will put a moratorium in place and ensure that applications are not processed.'

It is a national scandal that this is happening, but it is an even greater national scandal that the Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Hill, came in here and defended it and criticised the outcome rather than the fact that his colleagues—his respected colleagues, as he calls them, but no-one else in the country respects them—have put the moratorium on, and it is this moratorium that has meant that applications cannot be handled in the process. It is a scandal. You would have thought that there would be responsibility in this place on this government to ensure the proper functioning of the native title provisions. But, no, they just sit back and say, `Oh, isn't it terrible that we have got this backlog?' when they themselves know that not one application has been processed because the Northern Territory government has not triggered the process under section 29 of the Native Title Act. It is a scandal, and it is a scandal that has been raised in debate here.

At long last in this debate we have had vindication of the opposition's position. At long last we have had acknowledgment of the position of the opposition spokesman, Daryl Melham, in this area. He was ridiculed for some time and criticised for threats to the Western economy, security and whatever—all these things were thrown at him in the financial press and other parts of the media by people who did not take the time to understand. But at the end of the day we have acknowledgment by the father of the scheme, Senator Harradine, that there is a flaw in the system, and a flaw that needs to be fixed up. One person who should be vindicated tonight is Daryl Melham. Instead of putting themselves behind the barricades or in the trenches and taking a confrontationist approach, had the government listened to him earlier, had they acknowledged there was a problem, maybe we would not be going through this today.

That is something the government has got to cop the rap for, because there was a knee-jerk reaction—put your head in the ground and believe nothing wrong is happening. It is a knee-jerk reaction which led Daryl Williams to sign up to the first draft of this legislation, and it is a knee-jerk reaction which means that at the end of the day we are here at last acknowledging, through Senator Harradine, that there is a problem that needs to be fixed. I remind Senator Harradine that six to eight weeks ago I raised the same issue with him and someone was going to come back to me, but the phone has not yet rung. There probably does not need to be much more said than that. There is a problem in the legislation that needs to be fixed up.

I close on one particular point, and I am glad Senator Woodley is in here. Senator Woodley referred to the benchmarks in 43A(1)(b) of the legislation that will give some protection. I would ask you to have a close look at the letter from the Clerk of the Senate, Mr Harry Evans. One question I asked him is whether the Commonwealth minister could be compelled to revoke a determination under subsection 43A(9) if relevant alternative provisions fall below the threshold requirements of 43A(4), (6) and (7). You said there were threshold requirements and the provisions of a state or territory regime cannot fall below those requirements. I asked the Clerk whether in fact a Commonwealth minister could be compelled to revoke his or her approval, his or her determination, if the provisions fall below the threshold. This is the advice we got back from the Clerk of the Senate, and I think it is quite pertinent advice that needs to be put on the record again at this point in the debate. In relation to my second point, which was the question of provisions falling below the threshold requirements, the Clerk says:

It is also clear that there is nothing the Senate could do to compel the Commonwealth Minister to revoke a determination under 43A(9) even if the relevant state or territory provisions had been amended so that they no longer met the threshold conditions.

talk.start.para: —It is only a statutory obligation.
—That is precisely the point that we need to keep in mind as we go through the already signalled next part of this debate and these discussions. I will put this on the record as well.
—You think it is commonplace for Attorneys to ignore their statutory obligations, do you?
—I think the point you raise is quite a valid one, but it is addressed by the advice from the Clerk. He says:

speech.para: In that situation, the only possible way of compelling the Minister to revoke a determination would be to bring an action in the courts to seek a court order that the Minister revoke a determination. Apart from questions of standing, there would appear to be a significant hurdle in the way of such an action. Subsections 43A(4), (6) and (7) provide that alternative provisions meet the threshold test if `in the opinion of the Commonwealth Minister they provide for the matters set out in that subsection'. Such an action in the courts would therefore need to overturn not only a decision by the Minister not to revoke a determination but also the formation of the Minister's opinion as to the compliance of the alternative provisions with the threshold conditions.

talk.start.para: —It relies on Attorneys acting responsibly.
—First of all, Senator Hill, what a court would be asked to do is to overturn the minister's exercise of discretion.
—It does not have to go to court.
—Order!
—He said he would only take 30 seconds.
—If you would keep quiet, I might complete it quicker. That is something we need to take into consideration in the next part of this debate, which I am sure we are about to enter into.

speech.para: The other thing is that in this particular instance the Attorney-General has shown his hand. He agreed to legislation months ago, and that legislation has been amended four times now. What was acceptable to him in this process is no longer acceptable to the national parliament nor the Territory parliament. Basically what that shows is that discretion under this legislation is a very lethal discretion that can be exercised against native title holders and claimants. In closing the debate, I ask the Senate to support the opposition's disallowance motion.
Question put:
That the motion (Senator Bolkus's ) be agreed to.

talk.start.para: —The committee is considering the Regional Forest Agreements Bill 1998 and opposition amendments (R4) and (6), moved by Senator Forshaw. The question is that the amendments be agreed to.

—To refresh the committee's memory, at the moment we are dealing with the Labor amendments which would ensure that regional forest agreements from the mainland would be able to be vetted by each house of parliament. There are exceptions. They are the regional forest agreements for East Gippsland and the Central Highlands of Victoria, which for reasons which are unfathomable have been left off the list.

speech.para: Tasmania, which suffers two-thirds of the export woodchip industry eating into its forests, is also left out. That is because of the power of the Bacon Labor government in Tasmania to insist that the woodchippers' rights are pre-eminent in that state. Although world heritage forests are at stake, including enormous tracts of rainforest—and these are now ending up on the woodchip piles on the Burnie wharf en route to the Japanese paper mills—the Bacon government, which says it is in favour of making sure this industry works to the benefit of Tasmania, does not want the Senate or the House of Representatives to look at that agreement.

I reiterate here that hundreds of millions of dollars of taxpayers' money is going into this regional forest agreement process. It is unconscionable—to use the last word I used before this debate broke off yesterday—that the government should say to the taxpayers of Australia, `Well, we are putting hundreds of millions of dollars of your money basically into infrastructure to support the job shedding woodchip industry, but we don't want parliament to account for it.' I cannot think of any other example of such enormous amounts of money being out of the reach of parliamentary survey.

The Democrats moved an amendment to ensure that the Tasmanian, East Gippsland and Central Highlands RFAs were included but, though I supported that amendment, it failed in the Senate last night. So we are left with the regional forest agreements in the rest of the country to be at least vetted by the Senate. You will note that overnight I have added a new amendment here. I draw that to the government's and opposition's attention. Hopefully, through that, we will avoid the problem we have just been dealing with on native title. This amendment is to ensure that, where regional forest agreements are vetted by the Senate—

talk.start.para: —Are you moving an amendment to the opposition amendments?

—No, I am foreshadowing an amendment, Chair. The amendment is to ensure that there will not be a similar situation arise where the Prime Minister gets together with the Premier after the Senate has vetted the regional forest agreement and changes it. So I ask the opposition in particular to look at that overnight for consideration tomorrow, because it is an important amendment to this opposition amendment which I will be supporting.

speech.para: It goes without saying that the Greens have taken charge of defending Australia's forests in this matter. We think that it is reprehensible that the regional forest agreements are being signed without the parliament looking at them. We think it is reprehensible that Australia's forests are not subject to the protection of at least debate in the parliament before the Prime Minister goes off to see the Premier to give them over to the woodchippers. But be that as it may, we amend this bill where we can.
Progress reported.

talk.start.para: —Order! I propose the question:

talk.start.para: —Tonight I would like to speak again, as I have before, about the fringe benefits tax and the impact it has had in the more remote areas of Australia, particularly the north-west of Western Australia where I have a particular interest. It has to be said that the impact of the fringe benefits tax on development in the north of Western Australia has been quite devastating and has had a very negative impact on regional development. It has led to the loss of population in the north of Australia and led to the development of fly-in fly-out operations, which has meant that new towns have not been created.

speech.para: Most importantly, I would like to make the point tonight that, while the problems caused by the fringe benefits tax on the pastoral and mining industries in the more remote areas of Australia have been well recognised, the fact is that all businesses and non-taxable institutions, like local government, development commissions and so on—other independent non-taxable bodies in these areas—have also suffered very deleterious effects because of the fringe benefits tax.

The mining and petroleum industry in Australia provides around 82,000 direct jobs and 327,000 indirect jobs and, indeed, it makes a massive contribution to the Austral ian economy. The industry contributes some $60 billion annually to Australia's export markets, or 30 per cent of Australia's total exports. Mining and related industries generally operate in regional and remote areas of our country and, of course, are a big feature of the economy of the North-West of Western Australia. In recognition of the contribution that mining and related industries make to Australia's regional and national economies, and the potential these industries have to provide employment in regional and remote areas, the government has sought to exempt the mining industry from the fringe benefits tax on housing and matters associated with housing, like electricity for airconditioning. That was done in the last budget. In the previous budget, of course, the pastoral industry was exempted from the fringe benefits tax. While that is something I applaud and I think is a very important step—and it will certainly be a very important point in encouraging regional development—there is a very anomalous situation, as I said in my introduction, when it comes to small businesses in remote areas and businesses which might be associated with mineral extraction but not actually doing so by mining, such as the salt industry.

As far as small businesses and local government are concerned, you can have a town like Broome or Karratha or Kununurra where mining industry people have houses and the large mining companies are exempt from the fringe benefits tax paid on subsidies provided to their employees for housing and to cover the cost of electricity. But a subcontractor to those mining companies, or a body like local government—which also has to attract people to those areas and has to offer housing, electricity subsidies, cars, return air fares and so on—not only has to bear the cost of providing those attractions but also has to pay fringe benefits tax on them. This means that small business and non-taxable institutions like local government are put at a huge disadvantage in terms of the extra cost burden they have to bear in bringing people to the remote areas of Australia.

I think it is time that situation was considered and reformed, because it means that there is a significant inhibiting factor to regional development while those types of businesses and organisations are subject to fringe benefits tax. In fact, when one looks into the matter, one finds that in other countries that have a fringe benefits tax, like the United States, Canada and South Africa, the importance of not hindering regional development is recognised in their fringe benefits tax regimes and specific exemptions are made for all businesses, tax exempt organisations and institutions in remote areas so that they do not have to bear the additional cost burden that a fringe benefits tax puts on them in these areas.

I think that in this present atmosphere, where the whole of our tax regime is under review, it would be a very significant step forward for the Australian government to consider exempting all businesses in remote areas from fringe benefits tax on housing and on benefits which are required to attract employees to remote areas, because the people in remote areas, of course, are engaged in regional development. They are often playing a vital part in providing services to the major industries, which are usually the mining industries in those areas, and it is very important that they are encouraged in every possible way.
The Pilbara Development Commission recently published a report on the negative impact of the fringe benefits tax on regional development in the Pilbara. The report stated:

The present system of FBT in Australia has had a significantly negative impact on the development of the Pilbara since the introduction of this tax in 1986. Economic modelling results indicate that without FBT (and assuming an increase in income to compensate for FBT) the gross output of the region would have been 3.4% higher than under the existing system, over 670 additional jobs (supporting 1400 residents) would have been created, and an additional $14.5 million would have been invested and over $413 million in additional consumption expenditure would have been incurred. This is equivalent of an additional $50,000 for every retail establishment in the region. It is estimated that FBT costs business enterprises the equivalent of four jobs per establishment.

I think that is something we should all regret very much, because it shows the extent to which the fringe benefits tax is hindering regional development. A recent visit by Dampier Salt brought to my attention another anomaly in the present fringe benefits tax exemption regime. Dampier Salt has plants in the north of Western Australia which produce salt by evaporating sea water. They run sea water into large pans and that is evaporated down to salt, which is then harvested. They also have, near Carnarvon, a plant where they mine salt from a salt lake. For the plant near Carnarvon, the housing of its employees is FBT exempt because the salt is mined. In Karratha and Dampier, where they produce salt by an evaporation process, Dampier Salt has to pay fringe benefits tax on all the benefits paid to its employees, including housing. In the same streets as its employees there are homes of Woodside and Hamersley Iron employees. Those companies do not pay fringe benefits tax on the benefits paid to their employees in terms of housing because they are defined as mining companies.

This is an important issue in terms of regional development. I very strongly believe that, in the interest of promoting regional development, we should follow the example of Canada and provide exemptions for fringe benefits tax on all businesses and tax exempt organisations in the remote areas of Australia.

talk.start.para: —Almost 68 years ago, on 20 September 1931, Norman Leslie Gallagher was born. He grew up in Collingwood when its sense of community was high but the life of its citizens hard. People burnt Collingwood coke, the leather off-cuts from the local footwear industry, for heat. The smell permeated the air during those times of depression. Today Norm Gallagher was buried in the cemetery at Yarram where the air was clearer. He died last Thursday, 26 August 1999, three days before Collingwood, of whom he was an enduring supporter, played its last home game at Victoria Park.

speech.para: What formal education Norm Gallagher had was gained at St Joseph's Catholic Convent in Collingwood. He served on the altar at his local church. He played football with the Young Christian Workers. He boxed in the Golden Gloves and later professionally. In those days, children growing up in Collingwood had a limited range of jobs to look to for their future working lives. There were the boot factories, the clothing mills, the brewery, the local council—all of which were located within that suburb—or building sites or wharves further afield. All involved tough and repetitive tasks, bad conditions and poor pay.

Norm Gallagher left school when he was 13 and, having worked for a while in the boot trade and as a jockey on a truck, became a builder's labourer. He joined the union covering that industry and while in his teens was made an official of it. Ultimately he became Secretary of the Australian Building Construction Employees and Builders' Labourers Federation, better known as the BLF.

When Norm Gallagher started in the building industry, the lot of a labourer was a harsh and dangerous one, plagued by low wages and dirty and unsafe construction sites. When he departed it, things were immeasurably better. He and his union transformed what had previously been an appalling state of affairs into one where life and limb were as secure as could reasonably be, and working conditions were much more civilised. That his reforms have meant the saving of many lives and the prevention of innumerable injuries which would otherwise have occurred is indisputable.

The BLF, under Norm Gallagher, took industrial action which is still remembered vividly but in different ways by a variety of people and institutions. The building industry he knew was a rough and raw one. Soft negotiations had little chance of success. Issues at stake were high and included issues of life and limb. But there were other matters of moment that he was associated with, including the saving of places like the Victoria Market, the Regent Theatre and the City Baths.

Ted Hill was an eminent Melbourne barrister and a committed Marxist and had great influence over Norm Gallagher. Norm Gallagher had in pride of place on the wall of his office a photo of himself, Ted Hill and Mao Zedong, taken in Beijing. Today his coffin was piped to the grave to the tune of God Save Ireland, which shows that Norm Gallagher's life was affected by a range of factors.
Norm Gallagher was a member of the executive of the ACTU and was prominent on the Victorian Trades Hall Council.

As the 1980s developed, troubled times came upon Norm Gallagher. Shadows crossed his career. The processes of the law descended upon him and upon his union with shattering force. As time went by, old links and seemingly enduring structures were torn asunder.

It is proper that, while these matters be remembered, others of higher moment be balanced against them. We all have within us forces of light and forces of darkness. That is one of the great human truths. If there is an audit of life after death, there will be a balancing of the good things and the bad things all of us have done. Norm Gallagher was a public man whose best and worst was there for the public to see. What is undeniable is that many men, women and children have gained much from the reforms he instituted. There is every reason to accord greater credit than debit to his eternal account. He deserves to be remembered well.

talk.start.para: —I want to talk tonight in the brief moments available to me about a project proposed for the goldfields of Western Australia in one of the richest areas for minerals in the world. The project will rival that internationally famous project established by C.Y. O'Connor in the early part of this century. The project proposes to bring desalinated water from Esperance over 300 kilometres north to the joint townships of Kalgoorlie and Boulder.

speech.para: The project is envisaged to eventually proceed further north to the giant and now world renowned nickel and cobalt deposits of Murrin Murrin, which are being exploited by the publicly listed company, Anaconda. If that happened, the pipeline would be something like 700 kilometres long—if it went through Leonora—and would be the longest water pipeline in the world. Currently the C.Y. O'Connor Perth to Kalgoorlie water pipeline is something less than a metre in diameter and is something akin to 500 kilometres long rather than the proposed 700 kilometres.

I want to outline some of the benefits that would be derived from this visionary project if it is undertaken. The infrastructure proposed for the pipeline would significantly be on site. It can be either a conventional cement-lined steel pipeline or a new type of plastic pipeline that could be extruded on site. It is proposed to be about one metre in diameter and would be extruded in perhaps Esperance, Norseman or even Kalgoorlie. The route for the pipeline is along the current railway easement that travels from Kalgoorlie in a rather circuitous route through Coolgardie and down through Norseman to the port of Esperance.

The pipeline is desperately needed. Currently the mining industry is being somewhat inhibited by the cost involved in using the potable water from the Mundaring pipeline and the infrastructure costs that mining companies are required to contribute to that is not refundable by the Water Corporation. Also, because water is so expensive, some of the palaeo-channels—that is, fossil water—is exploited. This fossil water is either supersaline or hypersaline and can often be 12 times saltier than sea water—something akin to the Dead Sea. This creates metallurgical problems and requires more chemicals than would otherwise be needed if the water was potable.

This project is to be undertaken by a company called Goldfields Utilities Limited in conjunction with an American company called Global Environment Fund. Global Environment Fund specialises in funding water projects throughout the world and has a cross-shareholding with a company in America called The Atlantis Water Fund. The project envisages the extension of the Karratha to Kalgoorlie gas pipeline down to Esperance. It currently terminates in Kalgoorlie. It is envisaged that that would be extended to Esperance.

It must be remembered that the goldfields are, on average, about 1,000 feet—300 metres—above sea level and the pumping will require a significant engineering feat. It is not impossible. It is expensive, but not impossible. The synergy that has been suggested between the vast lignite deposits south of Norseman—north of Esperance—could also be used in the feasibility study. In situ production of ligneous gas to power the pumps along the proposed water pipeline could be utilised.

One of the great inhibiting factors of the goldfields development has always been the lack of water. Most goldfields people, like me, thank God for the visionary C.Y. O'Connor, who established one of the great pipelines of the world. It remained so until the early 1990s when a pipeline was built from the Red Sea port in Saudi Arabia to the capital city of Riyadh—a distance just exceeding that of C.Y. O'Connor's pipeline. So it was something like 90 years before a desalination plant was built in Saudi Arabia that exceeded the C.Y. O'Connor pipeline.

But it is not just for the benefit of the industry. With Australia being one of the signatories of the Kyoto Convention—handled so deftly, adroitly and astutely by Senator Robert Hill on behalf of Australian industry—that limited the emissions of greenhouse gas emissions, particularly CO2, it became obvious to the goldfields that, if the vast empty areas above what we call the `mulga line' could be utilised for plantation timber—particularly Eucalyptus globulus but not limited to that—some contra with respect to greenhouse gas emissions could be of great benefit to Australia also.

It is proposed that, if the pipeline is extended north from Kalgoorlie through Menzies, Leonora and ultimately to Murrin Murrin—one of the biggest developments this century in Western Australia in terms of its dollar expenditure—then those vast areas could be utilised for the contra of greenhouse gas emissions and, ultimately, for the use of plantation timbers. This would mean employment in the district, and that has the approval of the Aboriginal people who see the great benefit that developments of this nature can have for alternative employment for their children.

The project has the approval of the Premier of Western Australia, Richard Court, the Deputy Premier and Leader of the National Party in Western Australia, the Hon. Hendy Cowan, and government departments. What it needs is some assistance and encouragement from the federal government to undertake this $½ billion project that could be under way as soon as Christmas this year.

I believe that it is a significant project for Western Australia, and it is significant for Australia. It opens up what is otherwise extraordinarily undeveloped and empty country on that goldfields plateau of the Yilgarn Craton, and it has many benefits, not least of all the further expenditure of half a billion dollars in the goldfields—and with the downturn in gold prices, that can only be described as very desirable.

There is, however, one dichotomy that exists, and that is with respect to the Water Corporation. This is a wholly owned government subsidiary, corporatised from a utility. From information that I have received, I understand that it is undertaking its own feasibility study about bringing salt water from Esperance, roughly along the same route as with this potable water, and using sea water in the mining industry to alleviate the reduction of hypersaline and supersaline palaeo-channels—fossil waters. That can only be described as disastrous.

We need to get rid of our salt in Western Australia. We are working on it, and we are spending hundreds of millions of dollars on it. A government instrumentality, seemingly somewhat out of control, that wants to bring salt water up to Kalgoorlie is something that I think ought to be discouraged. Not only that, but it is unfair in terms of its opposition to a project that is quite clearly in the best interests of the public sector, and that can only be in the best interests of goldfields people. talk.start.para: —I rise tonight to talk about a very important although often overlooked issue, and that is the plight of Australians who are growing older with a mental illness. According to a new study by SANE—that is formerly the Schizophrenia Association—there are tens of thousands of older Australians who have a mental illness. I am not just talking about conditions which are generally associated with aging, such as dementia. I am talking about the whole spectrum of non-age-specific mental illnesses, including conditions such as schizophrenia, bipolar disorder and severe depression—conditions which are more likely to strike in younger adulthood and which are more likely to be appropriately treated when sufferers are young rather than when they are older. It is an unfortunate reflection on the attitudes which seem to prevail in today's society that, as people with mental disorders grow older, they are much more likely to be treated as though they are approaching their use-by date and therefore it is not worth spending money or effort on their care.

speech.para: According to SANE Australia, the majority of older Australians with a mental illness are hidden away. They are warehoused in dingy boarding houses with little or no support, and they are often on industrial strength doses of older medications which have not been reviewed. A recent report on the study undertaken by SANE Australia, entitled Senior Service? A national survey of services for older Australians with a mental illness, 1999, exposes widespread neglect of older Australians living with a mental illness. The findings contained in this report leave me with very little doubt that older Australians with a mental illness currently face a wide range of unmet needs. The report begins by asking if anything has really changed since 1993, when the statement was made that `In the competition for scarce mental health resources, the elderly take low priority.' That of course appeared in the Burdekin report into the human rights of people with a mental illness. Sadly, SANE Australia concludes that, in 1999, very little has changed. As the report puts it:

For the tens of thousands of Australians growing older with a mental illness, who still live in rundown boarding homes or are homeless, who remain on what one clinician has called industrial strength doses of older antipsychotic agents which are not reviewed, whose only clinical support is an occasional visit to a GP, and who receive no support to access rehabilitation and recreation, the answer would surely be `Not a lot has really changed.

In this, the International Year of Older Persons, SANE Australia is finding that people growing older with a mental illness are one of the most disadvantaged and vulnerable groups in Australian society. That is disappointing, and it is clearly unacceptable.

It is not fair, it seems to me, to ignore the unmet needs of older Australians living with a mental illness. There are already around 103,000 people over 60 affected by mental illness, and of course Australia's population, like that of many Western countries, is rapidly ageing. It is a widely accepted fact that, by the year 2001, 18 per cent of Australians will be over 60. By the year 2021, this figure is expected to have grown to a whopping 25 per cent. I think it must be assumed that this rapid growth will be accompanied by a rapid growth in the number of older Australians with mental illness and, of course, a rapid growth in the need for specific and appropriate services to assist them.

As SANE Australia rightly points out, there is now an urgent need to plan care for this group, and that includes support, mental health care and specialised accommodation. Responsibility for services needed by older Australians living with a mental illness is currently shared by the Commonwealth and the states and territories. The fact that neither tier of government has sole responsibility for these services means that neither has assumed responsibility and that both will pass the buck to the other all too readily.

Mental health services are funded by the states and territories together with local government, whilst aged care, frail aged services, residential aged care and community care packages are handled by the Commonwealth and, of course, partly by local government. Home and community care services are jointly funded by states and territories, local government and the Commonwealth. The needs of older Australians living with mental illness can therefore only be met with a joint effort between the three tiers of government.

SANE Australia's report suggests that policy makers need to begin by asking three broad questions when considering future strategies for addressing and funding needs in this area: what recognition is there of the treatment and support needs of people growing older with a mental illness, as distinct from people with age-related illnesses; what policies and funding are in place with a specific focus on people growing older with a mental illness; and what services actually exist for people growing older with a mental illness. When considering these questions, it is important to recognise that some regions are already doing better than others. In fact, according to SANE Australia, there are indeed some excellent programs already in place. However, as the report says, `The tragedy is that these programs remain isolated examples.'

Clearly, what should be happening now is that we should be looking at extending these programs, which have been shown to be successful in every state and territory in the country. I would like to finish with a quote from Associate Professor John Snowdon from the Royal Australian and New Zealand College of Psychiatrists, who said, on welcoming the work undertaken by SANE Australia, `So often the focus on the problems and tragedies of young adults with mental illness often seems blind to the continuing tragedy experienced by many older Australians.'

In this International Year of Older Persons, I call on the government to recognise, without further delay, the unmet needs of older Australians living with mental illness. I call on all tiers of government to work together to improve links between existing services and adopt a partnership approach to policies and funding affecting older Australians living with mental illness.

subdebateinfo.title: Civil Aviation Safety Authority: Staff External Studies
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 1196)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 13 July 1999:

question.para: (1) Does the Civil Aviation Safety Authority (CASA) encourage its employees to undertake external studies; if so, what direct financial assistance does CASA provide to employees undertaking further studies.
(2) How many hours per week are CASA employees able to spend away from their workplace to undertake studies.

(3) Are CASA employees who are undertaking external studies able to use CASA facilities, or resources, during or after work hours for that purpose; if so, what limits are placed on the use of CASA resources or facilities for external studies.

talker.name: Macdonald, Sen Ian
Senator Ian Macdonald
talker.role: Regional Services, Territories and Local Government

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Transport and Regional Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: The Civil Aviation Safety Authority (CASA) has advised that:

CASA has established a staff development program (the Program) which is designed to meet the professional needs of its officers. The Program acknowledges the need for certain officers to possess and maintain mandatory technical qualifications. It also recognises the benefits of staff undertaking further studies (and training) as part of their professional development.

During 1998-99, CASA spent approximately $1.6m on non-salary training expenses. This can be attributed to three main external forms—technical (aviation-related); tertiary (university, TAFE etc); and workplace related training. The Program is reviewed from time-to-time to reflect recommendations made by external inquiries such as Plane Safe, Seaview, Monarch and reports by the Australian National Audit Office.
As a general principle, CASA permits reasonable costs associated with training and where necessary has guidelines in place. CASA also permits reasonable access to resources and facilities.

(1) CASA provides at its discretion, assistance to staff who undertake external studies in the form of both leave and financial assistance. CASA's "Assistance to Employees for Study" provisions are contained in Section 3 of its Staff Policy Manual (SPM). A copy of that Section has been provided to the Table Office.

Essentially, CASA may provide approved students with 5 hours paid study leave per week during normal business hours together with up to an additional 3 hours travelling time per week, where the study activities are not available outside normal office hours. Paid leave may also be granted to travel to attend and return from examinations associated with an approved course. In addition, leave may also be granted to allow an employee to follow full-time study when the study is useful and relevant to CASA. Up to a maximum of 3 consecutive years unpaid leave may be approved.

Under the terms of Sub-Section 3.4 of the SPM (refer to the attachment), CASA reimburses compulsory tuition and examination fees as well as HECs fees subject to the successful completion of the studies.

For short courses, which are usually up to 200 hours in length, CASA may sponsor the employee by paying related costs, excluding the cost of books, if the employee is asked/directed to attend the course. The leave to attend is automatic in these circumstances.
(2) The time CASA employees are able to spend away from their workplace to undertake studies is covered in the answer to Question 1.

(3) Access to CASA facilities and resources by students undertaking external studies is at the discretion of local managers. Consideration for reasonable use of such resources would be given to employees undertaking studies which they have been asked/directed to undertake or which are deemed to be useful and relevant to CASA.

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Transport and Regional Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) The reported incident involving a Royal Australian Air Force P-3C Orion and a civilian aircraft, that occurred during the search for sailors participating in the Sydney Hobart yacht race, is a joint Directorate of Flying Safety—Australian Defence Forces (DFS-ADF)/BASI investigation.
The DFS-ADF has prime carriage of the investigation with BASI support. A joint BASI/ADF report will be released on completion of the investigation.
(2) (a) BASI was advised of this incident on 4 January 1999.
(b) The DFS-ADF.
(c) The investigation is continuing.
(3) A copy of the report will be forwarded to Senator O'Brien when it is completed.
